MIC2 is an adhesive protein that participates in host cell invasion by the obligate intracellular parasiteToxoplasma gondii. Earlier studies established that MIC2 is secreted into the culture medium by extracellular parasites and that release is coincident with proteolytic modification. Since little is known about proteolytic processing of proteins secreted by T. gondii, we undertook this study to investigate the proteolytic events that accompany secretion of MIC2. We demonstrate that the C-terminal domain of MIC2 is removed by a protease, termed MPP1, when MIC2 is released into the culture supernatant. Additionally, prior to release, a second protease, termed MPP2, trims the N terminus of MIC2, resulting in the release of heterogeneously sized species of MIC2. Although MPP1 activity was unaffected by any of the protease inhibitors tested, MPP2 activity was blocked by a subset of serine and cysteine protease inhibitors. These results establish that MIC2 is proteolytically modified at multiple sites by two distinct enzymes that probably operate on the parasite surface. MIC2 is an adhesive protein that participates in host cell invasion by the obligate intracellular parasiteToxoplasma gondii. Earlier studies established that MIC2 is secreted into the culture medium by extracellular parasites and that release is coincident with proteolytic modification. Since little is known about proteolytic processing of proteins secreted by T. gondii, we undertook this study to investigate the proteolytic events that accompany secretion of MIC2. We demonstrate that the C-terminal domain of MIC2 is removed by a protease, termed MPP1, when MIC2 is released into the culture supernatant. Additionally, prior to release, a second protease, termed MPP2, trims the N terminus of MIC2, resulting in the release of heterogeneously sized species of MIC2. Although MPP1 activity was unaffected by any of the protease inhibitors tested, MPP2 activity was blocked by a subset of serine and cysteine protease inhibitors. These results establish that MIC2 is proteolytically modified at multiple sites by two distinct enzymes that probably operate on the parasite surface. human foreskin fibroblast polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis 1,3-bis[tris(hydroxymethyl)methylamino]propane cytochalasin D l-1-chloro-3-[4-tosylamido]-7-amino-2-heptanone HCl N-acetyl-Leu-Leu-norleucinal N-acetyl-Leu-Leu-methioninal monoclonal antibody excretory secretory antigen Cell invasion is a critical step during infection of susceptible hosts by intracellular protozoan parasites. Although the mechanisms of parasite invasion vary considerably, a common theme includes the participation of parasite-derived proteases that have been described inLeishmania (1.Russell D.G. Wilhelm H. J. Immunol. 1986; 136: 2613-2620PubMed Google Scholar), Trypanosoma cruzi (2.Caler E.V. Vaena de Avalos S. Haynes P.A. Andrews N.W. Burleigh B.A. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 4975-4986Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar), andPlasmodium (3.Banyal H.S. Misra G.C. Gupta C.M. Dutta G.P. J. Parasitol. 1981; 67: 623-626Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar, 4.Dejkriengkraikhul P. Wilairat P. Z. Parasitenkd. 1983; 69: 313-317Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 5.Dluzewski A.R. Rangachari K. Wilson R.J.M. Gratzer W.B. Exp. Parasitol. 1986; 62: 416-422Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). In contrast, apart from a recent description of the effects of serine protease inhibitors (6.Conseil V. Soete M. Dubremetz J.-F. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1999; 43: 1358-1361Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), little is known regarding the involvement of proteases in host cell invasion by the related apicomplexan parasite Toxoplasma gondii. T. gondii is a widely distributed intracellular protozoan that parasitizes virtually all warm-blooded vertebrates, including humans. T. gondii tachyzoites (a rapidly dividing stage responsible for acute infection) actively invade host cells in several discrete steps. First, the parasite uses gliding motility to emerge from an infected cell, to move across the substratum, and to reach adjacent host cells (7.Hakansson S. Morisaki H. Heuser J. Sibley L.D. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1999; 10: 3539-3547Crossref PubMed Scopus (150) Google Scholar). Second, the parasite adheres via its apical (anterior) pole to the host cell (8.Aikawa M. Komata Y. Asai T. Midorikawa O. Am. J. Pathol. 1977; 87: 285-296PubMed Google Scholar, 9.Nichols B.A. O'Connor G.R. Lab. Invest. 1981; 44: 324-335PubMed Google Scholar). Third, using contractile proteins, including actin and myosin, the parasite penetrates the host cell (10.Dobrowolski J.M. Sibley L.D. Cell. 1996; 84: 933-939Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (529) Google Scholar, 11.Dobrowolski J.M. Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Mol. Microbiol. 1997; 26: 163-173Crossref PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar) to form a parasitophorous vacuole, in which it rapidly proliferates to produce additional infective tachyzoites. Notably,T. gondii is capable of invading a wide variety of host cells in vitro, suggesting that it expresses ligands that recognize receptors commonly expressed on the surface of vertebrate cells. Consistent with this idea, recent studies suggest that T. gondii uses ubiquitously expressed glycosaminoglycans as one of its receptors for invasion of host cells (12.Ortega-Barria E. Boothroyd J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 1267-1276Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar). 1V. B. Carruthers and L. D. Sibley, unpublished data. 1V. B. Carruthers and L. D. Sibley, unpublished data. Although ligands used by T. gondii to attach to host cells have yet to be characterized in detail, recent studies suggest that some adhesins may be released from apical secretory organelles called micronemes. For example, MIC1 possesses two degenerate adhesive sequences related to a domain of thrombospondin, and it is capable of binding host cells in vitro (13.Fourmaux M.N. Achbarou A. Mercereau-Puijalon O. Biderre C. Briche I. Loyens A. Odberg-Ferragut C. Camus D. Dubremetz J.-F. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1996; 83: 201-210Crossref PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar). Similarly, the 115-kDa antigen MIC2 harbors several thrombospondin-like repeat sequences (M-domain) and an integrin-like adhesive domain (I-domain) (14.Wan K.-L. Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Ajioka J.W. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1997; 84: 203-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar). One or both of these adhesive domains may be responsible for the host cell binding activity recently demonstrated for MIC2 (15.Carruthers, V. B., Giddings, O. K., and Sibley, L. D. (2000) Cell. Microbiol., in pressGoogle Scholar). MIC2 is mobilized from the micronemes to occupy the parasite apical surface at the time of attachment to host cells (16.Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Eur. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 73: 114-123PubMed Google Scholar). Thereafter, MIC2 relocates to the posterior end of the tachyzoite as the parasite penetrates into the host cell (15.Carruthers, V. B., Giddings, O. K., and Sibley, L. D. (2000) Cell. Microbiol., in pressGoogle Scholar). Collectively, these findings suggest that while on the cell surface, MIC2 participates in adhesion. Consistent with this model, a homologue of MIC2 expressed by Plasmodiumsporozoites is essential for invasion of host cells (17.Sultan A.A. Thathy V. Frevert U. Robson K.J. Crisanti A. Nussenzweig V. Nussenzweig R.S. Menard R. Cell. 1997; 90: 511-522Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (502) Google Scholar). Although we have previously shown that MIC2 is shed into the culture medium as several similarly sized species (14.Wan K.-L. Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Ajioka J.W. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1997; 84: 203-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar, 18.Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Mol. Microbiol. 1999; 31: 421-428Crossref PubMed Scopus (283) Google Scholar), the molecular details of this presumed proteolytic processing remain obscure. Here we show that two distinct parasite-derived proteases, denoted MPP1 and MPP2, process MIC2 at its C and N termini, respectively. We show here that MPP1 cleaves MIC2 proximal to its transmembrane anchor, releasing the adhesive domains of MIC2 into the culture medium, whereas MPP2 functions by trimming the N terminus of MIC2 down to the beginning of the integrin-like adhesive domain. T. gondii strain 2F was propagated in human foreskin fibroblast (HFF)2 cells as described (10.Dobrowolski J.M. Sibley L.D. Cell. 1996; 84: 933-939Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (529) Google Scholar). Tachyzoites were harvested from lysed out HFF cells after a 2-day passage by twice passing them through a 20-gauge needle followed by filtration through a 3-μm pore size membrane to remove host cell debris. Tachyzoites were washed twice by centrifugation (1000 ×g, 10 min, room temperature) in invasion medium (Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium, 3% fetal bovine serum, and 20 mmHEPES, pH 7.5) prior to use in experiments. For protease inhibitor experiments, tachyzoites (4 × 107/ml of invasion medium) were incubated for 3 min at 37 °C with 1% (v/v) ethanol to stimulate microneme secretion. For all other analytical secretion experiments, tachyzoites were incubated for 30 min at 37 °C before they were cooled to 0 °C to stop further secretion. Tachyzoites were removed by centrifugation (twice at 1000× g, 10 min, 4 °C) and supernatants were mixed with SDS-PAGE sample buffer containing 2.0% (v/v) 2-mercaptoethanol for SDS-PAGE and Western blotting (see below). To measure the effect of pH on MIC2 processing, tachyzoites were pelleted and resuspended in invasion medium containing 25 mm Tris and 25 mm bis-Tris propane at pH 5.75, 6.00, 6.25, 7.4, 8.5, 8.75, or 9.00 before assaying for secretion as described above. For cytochalasin D (CytD) and protease inhibitor experiments, tachyzoites were preincubated for 10 min at room temperature with 1% Me2SO (solvent control); 1 μm CytD; 5 μm pepstatin; 10 mm EDTA (sodium salt); 10 mm EGTA (sodium salt); 2 mm1,10-phenanthroline; 50 μg/ml matrix metalloprotease-1 inhibitor (MMP-1); 1, 10, or 50 μm 3,4-dichloroisocoumarin; 100 μm TLCK; 100 μm(4-amidinophenyl)methanesulfonyl fluoride; 10, 100, or 200 μm 4-(2-aminoethyl)benzenesulfonyl)fluoride hydrochloride; 1 mm phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride; 10 μg/ml chymostatin; 23 mm leupeptin; 10 μmE-64; and 40 μg/ml calpain inhibitor I (N-acetyl-Leu-Leu-norleucinal (ALLN)) or 40 μg/ml calpain inhibitor II (N-acetyl-Leu-Leu-methioninal (ALLM)) before being assayed for secretion as described above. Protease inhibitors were purchase from either Sigma or Roche Molecular Biochemicals. Except where otherwise noted, proteins were resolved on 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gels and semidry-transferred to nitrocellulose membranes for Western blotting. Western blotting was performed as described previously (14.Wan K.-L. Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Ajioka J.W. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1997; 84: 203-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar) using mAb 6D10 (ascites, 1:10,000), mouse anti-C-terminal domain antibody (MαC-dom; 1:10,000), rabbit anti-SAG1 antibody (1:5000), rabbit anti-Tg actin antibody (1:10,000), or mouse anti-H4 antibody (1:5:000). A subcellular fraction enriched in micronemes was prepared using a hybrid protocol derived from two previous studies (19.Dubremetz J.-F. Dissous C. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1980; 1: 279-289Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar, 20.Kawazoe U. Tomley F.M. Frazier J.A. Parasitology. 1992; 104: 1-9Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar). Briefly, ∼4 × 109 tachyzoites were harvested and resuspended in Hanks' balanced salt solution containing 10 mm HEPES and 1 mm EGTA (HHE buffer ) at 0 °C. The parasite suspension was sonicated (2 × 15-s pulses, setting 35 on a Biosonik III sonicator (Bronwill Scientific) equipped with a microprobe) on ice. Lysis was determined to be >90% by microscopic examination. Unbroken parasites and large cellular debris were removed by successive centrifugation steps at 2000 × g for 10 min at 4 °C and at 8000 × g for 20 min at 4 °C. Intact micronemes were recovered by centrifugation at 30,000 ×g for 30 min at 4 °C. Most secretory proteins from other secretory organelles (dense granules and rhoptries) remained in the 30,000 × g supernatant (data not shown). The 30,000 × g pellet was rinsed once with HHE buffer and resuspended in bis-Tris propane (25 mm, pH 6.0)-buffered saline (150 mm NaCl) containing 100 μm TLCK, 100 μm (4-amidinophenyl)methanesulfonyl fluoride, 2.3 mm leupeptin, 10 μm E-64, and 40 μg/ml ALLN. Saponin (Sigma) was added to a final concentration of 0.01% (w/v), and the fraction was incubated for 10 min at 4 °C. Insoluble material was removed by centrifugation (100,000 × g, 30 min, 4 °C), and the supernatant containing the enriched microneme protein fraction was aliquoted and stored at −80 °C. Western blot analysis demonstrated that this fraction was enriched >20-fold for micronemal antigens over most other secretory antigens (i.e.from dense granules or rhoptries) or surface antigens. For large-scale ESAs, ∼3 × 109 tachyzoites were resuspended in HHE buffer and preincubated for 10 min at room temperature with 1% Me2SO, 40 μg/ml ALLN, or 1 μm CytD. Microneme secretion was stimulated by incubation at 37 °C for 10 min with 1% (v/v) ethanol (21.Carruthers V.B. Moreno S.N.J. Sibley L.D. Biochem. J. 1999; 342: 379-386Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar). Tachyzoites were removed by centrifugation (1200 × g, 10 min, 4 °C), and culture supernatants containing ESAs were concentrated 20-fold in Centricon-10® concentrators (Amicon, Inc.), aliquoted, and stored at −80 °C. The enriched microneme fraction and large-scale ESA preparations were mixed with SDS-PAGE sample buffer containing 2.0% 2-mercaptoethanol and heated at 95 °C for 3 min. Proteins (∼5 μg/lane) were resolved on 10% SDS-polyacrylamide gels, transferred to Immobilon® PSQ membranes (Millipore Corp.), and stained with Coomassie Brilliant Blue R-250. Bands were excised and subjected to Edman degradation on a Perkin-Elmer Biosystems Model 477A Gas-Phase Protein Sequencer. For determining the membrane topology of surface MIC2 during invasion, HFF monolayers grown in Lab-Tek chamber slides (Nunc, Inc.) were pulse-infected with tachyzoites and stained as described previously (16.Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Eur. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 73: 114-123PubMed Google Scholar). Where indicated, saponin (0.05%) was used to permeabilize parasites. Parasites were stained with affinity-purified RαrM2 (1:10) (14.Wan K.-L. Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Ajioka J.W. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1997; 84: 203-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar) and MαC-dom (1:200; see below for description) followed by fluorescently conjugated secondary antibodies (Jackson ImmunoResearch Laboratories, Inc., West Grove, PA). Slides were examined and photographed on a Zeiss Axioscope equipped for phase-contrast and epifluorescence microscopy. Preparation of recombinant MIC2 (ectodomain) has been described previously (14.Wan K.-L. Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Ajioka J.W. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1997; 84: 203-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar). DNA encoding the C-terminal domain of MIC2 (residues 727–769) was polymerase chain reaction-amplified (94 °C for 5 min and then 20 cycles of 94 °C for 40 s, 65 °C for 1 min, and 72 °C for 1 min and a final extension at 72 °C for 5 min) from a tachyzoite cDNA library (22.Wan K.-L. Blackwell J.M. Ajioka J.W. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1996; 75: 179-186Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar) using Klentaq polymerase (Invitrogen) and primers MICW.721.F (5′-AGTTACCACTACTATTTGAGCT-3′) and MICW.2306.R (5′-GATCCTCGAGCTACTCCATCCACATATCACT-3′). The resulting polymerase chain reaction product was gel-purified and digested withSacI (which cleaved a natural restriction site present at nucleotide 2182 relative to the first nucleotide of the initiator methionine) and XhoI (which cleaved at a site engineered into MICW.2306.R). The restricted polymerase chain reaction product was then gel-purified again and ligated intoSacI/XhoI-digested and gel-purified pScreen1b (Novagen). This resulted in a translational fusion of the T7 phage gene 10 product (encoded by pScreen1b) to the C-terminal domain of MIC2. The ligation mixture was electrotransformed into Escherichia coli strain XL1-Blue, and the resulting transformants were screened for inserts. A randomly chosen clone bearing the C-terminal domain insert was transferred to E. coli strain BL21 for expression. Gene 10/C-terminal domain fusion protein was purified by nickel chelation chromatography using a His-Bind column (Novagen) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Gene 10 protein (expressed by pScreen1b) was also purified in the same manner. For production of antisera to gene 10 protein and gene 10/C-terminal domain fusion protein, Balb/c mice were immunized with 30 μg of each protein in Freund's complete adjuvant. At 2-week intervals, mice were twice boosted with 8 μg of protein, and blood was collected by cardiac puncture 3 weeks after the final boost. Antiserum to the fusion protein is referred to as MαC-dom. Freshly harvested tachyzoites (∼5 × 108) were resuspended in invasion medium containing 1 μm CytD and used to infect monolayers of HFFs by incubation for 30 min at 37 °C with CO2. Following infection, monolayers were washed with phosphate-buffered saline containing 1 mm CaCl2 and 1 mm MgCl2 at room temperature and treated with Me2SO (negative control) or 50 μg/ml sulfosuccinimidobiotin (Pierce) in Me2SO for 30 min at room temperature. Monolayers were washed and solubilized (1 h, 0 °C) in radioimmune precipitation assay buffer (50 mm Tris, pH 7.4, 1% Triton X-100, 0.5% sodium deoxycholate, 0.2% SDS, 100 mm NaCl, and 5 mm EDTA (sodium salt)) supplemented with 10 μg/ml RNase A, 20 μg/ml DNase I, and protease inhibitors (see above). Insoluble material was removed by centrifugation (13,000 × g, 15 min, 4 °C). After adjustment to pH 8.0 with 1 m NaOH, streptavidin-agarose (Sigma) was added (50% slurry in radioimmune precipitation assay buffer) and incubated for 1 h at room temperature with agitation. Streptavidin-agarose beads were pelleted by centrifugation (1000 × g, 1 min, room temperature), and proteins in the supernatant (SA-S) were acetone-precipitated and solubilized in SDS-PAGE sample buffer. Streptavidin-agarose beads were washed with radioimmune precipitation assay buffer, and proteins in the pellet (SA-P) were solubilized in SDS-PAGE sample buffer. Samples were aliquoted and stored at −20 °C. We have previously shown that MIC2 is released into the culture medium from extracellular tachyzoites as a secreted/excreted antigen (ESA) (14.Wan K.-L. Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Ajioka J.W. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1997; 84: 203-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar,18.Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Mol. Microbiol. 1999; 31: 421-428Crossref PubMed Scopus (283) Google Scholar). The released forms of MIC2 (MIC295–100) were 15–20 kDa smaller than cellular MIC2 (MIC2115) when analyzed by SDS-PAGE, suggesting that the released forms are proteolytically processed. To examine this further, we used a mAb (6D10) specific to the M-domain of MIC2 (Fig. 1 A) and a mouse anti-C-terminal domain antibody (MαC-dom) to determine if they could recognize the released forms of MIC2 (MIC295–100). The results (Fig. 1 B) indicate that although mAb 6D10 recognized both the cellular and released forms (MIC2115 and MIC295–100, respectively), MαC-dom recognized only the cellular form (MIC2115). These results imply that the released forms (MIC295–100) were produced by proteolytic removal of the C-terminal domain from the cellular form (MIC2115) and that this event was coincident with release of MIC295–100 into the supernatant (ESA). These experiments were carried out in the absence of host cells, suggesting that a parasite-derived protease was responsible for generating the released forms (MIC295–100). We named this protease MPP1 (microneme proteinprotease 1). The 15–20-kDa size reduction we observed for MIC2 after release is also consistent with cleavage occurring just N-terminal to the transmembrane sequence. Although the released forms (MIC295–100) were easily detectable in the ESA fraction, we failed to detect the C-terminal peptide either in the parasites or in the ESA fraction, even after long exposures. We also failed to detect the C-terminal peptide after briefly treating parasites with highly effective stimulators of microneme secretion, including A23187 (18.Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Mol. Microbiol. 1999; 31: 421-428Crossref PubMed Scopus (283) Google Scholar) and ethanol (21.Carruthers V.B. Moreno S.N.J. Sibley L.D. Biochem. J. 1999; 342: 379-386Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar) (data not shown). These results suggest that the C-terminal peptide is rapidly degraded after removal from the cellular form (MIC2115). In a previous study, we showed that MIC2 is secreted onto the apical surface of the parasite during attachment, and then it redistributes to the posterior end as the parasite penetrates into the host cell (15.Carruthers, V. B., Giddings, O. K., and Sibley, L. D. (2000) Cell. Microbiol., in pressGoogle Scholar). Having demonstrated that the released forms of MIC2 (MIC295–100) do not possess the C-terminal domain, we wanted to determine whether surface MIC2 retains the C-terminal domain. To do this, we used immunofluorescence microscopy and antibodies specific to the extracellular adhesive domains (RαrM2) and the C-terminal domain (MαC-dom). In the presence of saponin, both antibodies exclusively stained the apical region of extracellular parasites (Fig. 2, first row), indicating that they specifically recognize the micronemes by immunofluorescence. Consistent with the results of a previous study (16.Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Eur. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 73: 114-123PubMed Google Scholar), little or no detectable fluorescence staining for MIC2 was observed on the surface of extracellular parasites in the absence of detergent (data not shown). During invasion of host cells, RαrM2 detected MIC2 on the posterior surface of the parasite regardless of whether the cells were permeabilized (Fig. 2, second andthird rows), consistent with the presence of MIC2 on the surface of the parasite during invasion as described previously (15.Carruthers, V. B., Giddings, O. K., and Sibley, L. D. (2000) Cell. Microbiol., in pressGoogle Scholar). In contrast, MαC-dom recognized only MIC2 on the posterior end of parasites that were permeabilized with saponin (Fig. 2, second row). Collectively, these results indicate that the C-terminal domain remains associated with MIC2 as it translocates toward the posterior end of the parasite. Since MIC2 possesses a hydrophobic sequence of sufficient length to span a membrane (14.Wan K.-L. Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Ajioka J.W. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1997; 84: 203-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar), these results suggest that MIC2 is a transmembrane protein while on the parasite surface. Several lines of evidence suggest that the C-terminal cleavage of MIC2 is a functionally important event both prior to and during invasion. Prior to invasion, extracellular parasites secrete MIC2 at a low basal rate, mobilizing it from the micronemes to the parasite surface as an integral membrane protein (this study and Ref. 18.Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Mol. Microbiol. 1999; 31: 421-428Crossref PubMed Scopus (283) Google Scholar). Since no evidence of re-internalization has been observed, it appears that C-terminal cleavage serves to remove MIC2 from the parasite surface, thereby preventing its accumulation and limiting its vulnerability as a target for neutralizing antibodies. During invasion, microneme secretion is significantly up-regulated (16.Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Eur. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 73: 114-123PubMed Google Scholar), and an increased amount of MIC2 is discharged onto the parasite's surface, where some of it localizes to the moving junction (15.Carruthers, V. B., Giddings, O. K., and Sibley, L. D. (2000) Cell. Microbiol., in pressGoogle Scholar), which is a zone of tight apposition of the parasite and host cell membranes formed at the time of apical attachment. The moving junction is thought to be the site of parasite ligand and host receptor engagement (23.Dubremetz J.-F. Trends Microbiol. 1998; 6: 27-30Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). Recent binding studies suggest that MIC2 is capable of binding to host cell receptors (15.Carruthers, V. B., Giddings, O. K., and Sibley, L. D. (2000) Cell. Microbiol., in pressGoogle Scholar). Interestingly, full-length MIC2 (MIC2115) readily bound to host cells, whereas the C-terminally processed forms (MIC295–100) failed to bind. These data suggest that C-terminal cleavage reduces the affinity of the adhesive domains for host cell receptors. Thus, C-terminal cleavage may be responsible for disengaging receptors just prior to completing invasion. This is probably a key event since receptor disengagement at the terminal stage of penetration is likely a prerequisite for fission of the parasitophorous vacuole and the host plasma membrane. To further characterize the surface form of MIC2, we treated parasites with CytD, which arrests parasites at the stage of apical attachment. Immunofluorescence staining of CytD-arrested parasites confirmed that MIC2 was present on the apical surface of attached parasites (Fig.3 A). To specifically label surface MIC2, we used the non-membrane-permeable, amine-reactive compound sulfosuccinimidobiotin. After surface biotinylation, infected monolayers were detergent-solubilized and incubated with streptavidin-agarose. Centrifugation was used to partition biotinylated proteins into the streptavidin pellet fraction (SA-P) and unlabeled proteins into the supernatant (SA-S). Although we expected to detect the full-length cellular form of MIC2 (MIC2115) on the parasite surface (SA-P fraction), surprisingly little of this form was detected. Instead, a species migrating at 110 kDa (MIC2110) was apparent (Fig. 3 B). This ∼5-kDa reduction in apparent molecular mass was not due to biotin labeling because other labeled parasite proteins (e.g. SAG1) did not exhibit a change in mobility. The sharp appearance and slower mobility of the MIC2110 band clearly distinguished it from the released forms (MIC295–100) detected in an ESA preparation. Also, unlike the released forms (MIC295–100), surface MIC2 (MIC2110) possessed at least some portion of the C-terminal domain, based on reactivity with MαC-dom (Fig. 3 B). It is possible that the surface form (MIC2110) was generated by limited proteolysis of the C-terminal domain, leaving at least one epitope recognized by MαC-dom. However, since removal of ∼5 kDa from the C terminus of the cellular form (MIC2115) would likely eliminate the entire C-terminal domain, these results suggest that MIC2 is instead processed at its N terminus while on the parasite surface. As controls for labeling and partitioning, we probed Western blots with antibodies to SAG1, a well characterized surface antigen, and actin, a cytosolic marker. As expected, SAG1 was mainly in SA-P, whereas parasite actin was exclusively in SA-S (Fig. 3 B). Similarly, unlabeled cellular MIC2 (MIC2115) from micronemal stores was detected in SA-S (Fig. 3 B). Since studying proteolytic processing of surface MIC2 is limited by the low amounts of material, we decided to further characterize the protease(s) that act upon MIC2 by monitoring the proteolytic products present in ESA (i.e. MIC295–100). To examine the sensitivity of the MIC2 protease(s) to protease inhibitors, we treated extracellular tachyzoites with inhibitors effective against each class of protease. As shown in Fig.4 A, proteolytic processing of MIC2 was affected by a subset of protease inhibitors, including chymostatin and two calpain inhibitors, ALLN and ALLM. These compounds inhibited the formation of the smallest species of MIC2 (MIC295). Although they partially inhibited microneme secretion (based on detection of a control unprocessed microneme protein, H4 (24.Johnson A.M. Illana S. Gene (Amst.). 1991; 99: 127-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar)), chymostatin, ALLN, and ALLM did not substantially affect the release of MIC2 from the surface of the parasite, suggesting that they inhibit a protease that is distinct from MPP1. Thus, we will hereafter call the MIC295-forming protease MPP2. Although calpain-like proteases typically require calcium for high level activity, chelating calcium with EGTA had little or no effect on the formation of MIC295. Furthermore, calpain proteases are sensitive to leupeptin and E-64 (25.Kumar A. Shafiq S. Wadgaonkar R. Stracher A. Cell. Mol. Biol. 1992; 38: 477-483PubMed Google Scholar), which had no effect on MPP2 activity. Thus, despite the effectiveness of calpain inhibitors, these observations suggest that MPP2 may not be a calpain-like enzyme. Rather, based on its inhibition by chymostatin, MPP2 may be a chymotrypsin-like serine protease. Several other protease inhibitors affected the amount of MIC2 in ESA by inducing parasite lysis or by affecting microneme secretion directly. For example, EDTA and 1,10-phenanthroline produced partial lysis of parasites based on detection of a control cytoplasmic protein, β-galactosidase. Despite inducing some parasite lysis, the main effect of 1,10-phenanthroline was an inhibition of microneme secretion based on reduced abundance of MIC2 and H4 in ESA. Independently, 1,10-phenanthroline was observed to inhibit the secretion of MIC2 and MIC4 by extracellular parasites. 3J. L. Lovett and L. D. Sibley, unpublished data. The highest concentration of dichloroisocoumarin tested (50 μm) also inhibited microneme secretion, whereas lower concentrations had an inducing effect. Notably, high concentrations of dichloroisocoumarin were recently found to inhibit tachyzoite invasion of host cells (6.Conseil V. Soete M. Dubremetz J.-F. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1999; 43: 1358-1361Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Since microneme secretion is likely required for invasion of host cells (15.Carruthers, V. B., Giddings, O. K., and Sibley, L. D. (2000) Cell. Microbiol., in pressGoogle Scholar), our current results suggest that the inhibitory effects of dichloroisocoumarin on parasite invasion may be related to an inhibition of microneme secretion rather than an effect of proteolysis. On the other hand, we found that 4-(2-aminoethyl)benzenesulfonyl)fluoride hydrochloride actually stimulated microneme secretion, yet it markedly inhibited tachyzoite invasion (6.Conseil V. Soete M. Dubremetz J.-F. Antimicrob. Agents Chemother. 1999; 43: 1358-1361Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), suggesting that a serine protease(s) activity (unrelated to MIC2 processing) may indeed be required for efficient invasion of host cells. In an experiment to determine the pH optimum for proteolytic processing of MIC2, we found that MPP2 was inactive below pH 6.25 (Fig.4 B). MPP2 activity also appeared to be inhibited at pH >8.5, although the total amount of released MIC2 also declined above this pH. These results suggest that MPP2 is likely a neutral protease. Previously, we demonstrated that the posterior re-localization of MIC2 occurs in the absence of host cells and is blocked by CytD (18.Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Mol. Microbiol. 1999; 31: 421-428Crossref PubMed Scopus (283) Google Scholar), suggesting that MIC2 is associated with the actin cytoskeleton of the parasite. To determine if CytD affects MIC2 processing, we preincubated extracellular tachyzoites with CytD before preparing an ESA fraction from the treated parasites. As shown in Fig. 5, CytD treatment resulted in preferential accumulation of the smallest released form of MIC2 (MIC295) in the ESA fraction. CytD did not directly alter migration of MIC2 on SDS-polyacrylamide gels since addition of CytD to ESAs prepared from untreated tachyzoites failed to produce the same effect (data not shown). A possible explanation for these results is that MPP2 may be restricted to the apical surface of the tachyzoite and that CytD treatment traps surface MIC2 in the same vicinity, thereby facilitating processing before release into the supernatant. As described above, two species of MIC2 (MIC2115 and MIC2110) were detectable on the surface of apically attached parasites. Also, since MIC2110 has an intact C terminus, it is likely the product of N-terminal proteolytic processing of MIC2115. Since the size differential between the surface forms of MIC2 (∼5 kDa) is the same as that between the secreted forms (MIC2100 and MIC295), we hypothesized that MIC295 is also a product of N-terminal processing. To test this hypothesis, we determined the N-terminal sequences of MIC2115 and the secreted forms of MIC2 using large-scale ESA preparations and a subcellular fraction of tachyzoites that is enriched in micronemal antigens (Fig.6 A). Unambiguous sequences were obtained for each species of MIC2, and these were found to match sequences in the N-terminal region of MIC2 (Fig. 6 B) (14.Wan K.-L. Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Ajioka J.W. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1997; 84: 203-214Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar). An 8-residue N-terminal sequence (SIVDALRK) from cellular MIC2 (MIC2115) matched a sequence adjacent to the predicted secretory leader peptide, indicating that cellular MIC2 is not secondarily processed during transit through the secretory pathway or storage in micronemes. These data are consistent with earlier data from pulse-chase metabolic labeling experiments showing that MIC2 does not change in size for at least 1 h after it is synthesized (26.Achbarou A. Mercereau-Puijalon O. Autherman J.M. Fortier B. Camus D. Dubremetz J.-F. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1991; 47: 223-234Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar). The same N-terminal sequence (SIVDALRK) was also obtained from the largest released form (MIC2100), enriched by ALLN treatment, confirming that this form corresponds to MIC2115 minus the C-terminal domain. The smallest released form (MIC295, CytD-enriched) yielded an N-terminal sequence (AAEGCTNQL) that began 38 amino acids downstream of the N terminus of cellular MIC2 (MIC2115). A mixture of sequences (one primary and one secondary) was obtained from the species of MIC2 present in the 95–98-kDa region of ESA prepared in the absence of drug. No obvious tertiary or quaternary sequences were observed during analysis of the 95–98-kDa species, suggesting that two incompletely processed species predominated. Since their production was inhibited by ALLN, these species (MIC295–98) are likely the result of N-terminal processing by MPP2. Taken together, these results suggest that MPP2 cleaves MIC2 at several sites in its N terminus, culminating in the production of MIC295, which is the fully processed species. The functional significance of MPP2 processing of MIC2 is unclear since only a fraction of the secreted MIC2 is N-terminally processed. Furthermore, chymostatin or ALLN failed to significantly reduce tachyzoite invasion of host cells in vitro (data not shown). Further experiments will be required to determine whether N-terminal processing of MIC2 has a subliminal effect on invasion, perhaps by increasing the affinity of MIC2 for receptors or by altering its interaction with other parasite proteins. We demonstrate here that MIC2 is modified by two parasite-derived proteases, MPP1 and MPP2, following its secretion from the micronemes. MPP1 and MPP2 are likely active on the surface of the parasite based on the following observations. 1) In tachyzoite lysates, MIC2 is a single species of 115 kDa, suggesting that MIC2 is not proteolytically modified during storage in micronemes. 2) On the surface of apically attached tachyzoites, N-terminal truncation of MIC2 reduces its size by ∼5 kDa, which is consistent with modification by MPP2. 3) Kinetic analysis (data not shown) of MIC2 species in ESA suggests that MPP2 does not act upon MIC2 after it is released from the parasite. 4) The C-terminal domain of MIC2 is not detectable on the released forms of MIC2 (MIC295–100), suggesting that MPP1 acts upon MIC2 coincident with its release from the tachyzoite. Based on the above evidence, we constructed a model that depicts the most likely genesis of each of the MIC2 species observed (Fig.7). We propose that cellular MIC2 (MIC2115) is mobilized from the micronemes to the tachyzoite surface membrane, where it experiences one of two alternative fates. If cellular MIC2 immediately encounters MPP2, MPP2 cleaves its N terminus to generate the predominant surface form of MIC2 (MIC2110). Subsequent C-terminal cleavage of surface MIC2 by MPP1 then generates the smallest released form of MIC2 (MIC295). Alternatively, if cellular MIC2 encounters MPP1 first, MPP1 cleaves the C terminus of MIC2, generating the largest released form of MIC2 (MIC2100). However, the presence of multiple species of MIC2 (MIC295–100) in the culture supernatants indicates that N-terminal processing by MPP2 is often incomplete at the time of C-terminal cleavage by MPP1. We observed that CytD, which prevents the posterior re-localization of MIC2 (18.Carruthers V.B. Sibley L.D. Mol. Microbiol. 1999; 31: 421-428Crossref PubMed Scopus (283) Google Scholar), enhanced N-terminal processing of MIC2 by MPP2. This indicates that MPP2 may be restricted to the apical surface of the parasite since CytD treatment would effectively trap MIC2 with MPP2, thereby increasing the likelihood of N-terminal processing. Although it remains uncertain where MPP1 is located, the observation that surface MIC2 retains its C-terminal domain as it translocates rearward during parasite invasion suggests that MPP1 may cleave MIC2 on the posterior surface of the parasite. However, MPP1 may not be strictly limited to the posterior surface since CytD treatment does not affect MPP1-mediated release of MIC2 from the parasite in the absence of host cells (e.g.Fig. 5). Together with this work, earlier studies suggest that proteolytic processing may be a common mechanism for releasing adhesive proteins from invasive apicomplexan parasites. For example, the C-terminal cytoplasmic domain of Plasmodium knowlesi DBP-1 (Duffy-bindingprotein-1) is proteolytically removed upon release of the DBP-1 ectodomains into the culture medium (27.Adams J.H. Hudson D.E. Torii M. Ward G.E. Wellems T.E. Aikawa M. Miller L.H. Cell. 1990; 63: 141-153Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (246) Google Scholar). Also, the 235-kDa erythrocyte-binding antigen of Plasmodium yoeliiis a transmembrane protein that is proteolytically processed upon release into the culture supernatant (28.Ogun S.A. Holder A.A. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1996; 76: 321-324Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). Finally, MSP-1 (major surfaceprotein-1) of Plasmodium falciparumis proteolytically released from the surface of merozoites during invasion of erythrocytes (29.Blackman M.J. Holder A.A. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1992; 50: 307-315Crossref PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). Since adhesive proteins play a key role in attachment and invasion of target host cells, inhibition of these processing events may therefore inhibit parasite invasion, offering a potential target for therapeutic intervention. Future studies involving the molecular characterization of parasite-derived proteases such as MPP1 and MPP2 should shed light upon the precise role of proteases in invasion of host cells by T. gondii. In yeast, efficient protein transport across the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) membrane may occur co-translationally or post-translationally. The latter process is mediated by a membrane protein complex that consists of the Sec61p complex and the Sec62p-Sec63p subcomplex. In contrast, in mammalian cells protein translocation is almost exclusively co-translational. This transport depends on the Sec61 complex, which is homologous to the yeast Sec61p complex and has been identified in mammals as a ribosome-bound pore-forming membrane protein complex. We report here the existence of ribosome-free mammalian Sec61 complexes that associate with two ubiquitous proteins of the ER membrane. According to primary sequence analysis both proteins display homology to the yeast proteins Sec62p and Sec63p and are therefore named Sec62 and Sec63, respectively. The probable function of the mammalian Sec61-Sec62-Sec63 complex is discussed with respect to its abundance in ER membranes, which, in contrast to yeast ER membranes, apparently lack efficient post-translational translocation activity. We therefore set out to identify and characterize such proteins of the mammalian ER.We show here, that the mammalian ER contains proteins that display structural homology to the yeast Sec62p and Sec63p. Both proteins are expressed ubiquitously, and their abundance is similar to that of known components of the ER translocation machinery. To gain an indication as to the function of these proteins, we analyzed their molecular environment in the ER using different biochemical methods. We found that Sec62 and Sec63 are associated with Sec61 complexes, indicating that these proteins might be involved in transport processes similar to those performed by the yeast Sec complex. The association was only detectable in the absence of tightly bound ribosomes. This suggests that the function of Sec62 and Sec63 is most likely not directly linked to the co-translational protein translocation across the mammalian ER.DISCUSSIONThe data presented here demonstrate that the mammalian Sec61α can be found in a protein complex with structural similarity to the yeast Sec complex. In addition to the components of the trimeric Sec61 complex, Sec61α, Sec61β, and Sec61γ, this larger complex contains at least two other membrane proteins. These proteins, Sec62 and Sec63, display homology to the yeast proteins Sec62p and Sec63p, respectively. Remarkably, for both proteins, regions with significant homology were those exposed to the ER lumen or located close to the cytosolic surface of the membrane. The more distal cytosolic parts were very divergent. While this manuscript was in preparation, Skowronek et al.(40.Skowronek M.H. Rotter M. Haas I. Biol. Chem. Hoppe-Seyler. 1999; 380: 1133-1138Crossref PubMed Scopus (53) Google Scholar) also published the existence of the mammalian Sec63 and showed that it has the same membrane topology as the yeast protein. Both Sec62 and Sec63 were ubiquitously expressed in the rough ER of mammals, and the expression level of Sec62 in a particular tissue is roughly the same in all species tested. However, we cannot exclude that the abundance of Sec63 differs between species, because the epitope recognized by our anti-Sec63 antibodies is not conserved among mammals. Sec62 was also very abundant in smooth membranes that are essentially free of Sec61 complex. This is in agreement with our observation that Sec62 is expressed at high levels in the adrenal gland 2H. Grau and E. Hartmann, unpublished information. and that the mRNA is abundant not only in liver and pancreas but also in muscle tissues (39.Daimon M. Susa S. Suzuki K. Kato T. Yamatani K. Sasaki H. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1997; 230: 100-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar).Although Sec62 and Sec63 were abundantly expressed, the actual concentration of Sec61-Sec62-Sec63 complexes in the ER appears to be relatively low. Regardless of the detergent used, and whether the purification started with RM or with PK-RM, only about 5% of Sec61 and about 30% of Sec63 were found in a complex. In each case the molar ratio between Sec61α and Sec63 in the complex appeared to be 1:1 to 1:2. The binding of Sec63 to the complex was stable, whereas the association of Sec62 with this complex was much weaker. Under optimized purification conditions, we found about 15% of the Sec62 co-purified with Sec61β. However, in the cross-linking experiment 30% of the Sec62 was linked to Sec61β. In the same samples less than 5% of the Sec61β was in proximity to Sec62, similar to that found with Sec63. Therefore the amount of Sec62 and Sec63 in these complexes was likely to be the same. If one assumes that 3 to 4 pentameric Sec61-Sec62-Sec63 units form a translocation pore as it has been shown for the trimeric complex (5.Hanein D. Matlack K.E. Jungnickel B. Plath K. Kalies K.U. Miller K.R. Rapoport T.A. Akey C.W. Cell. 1996; 87: 721-732Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (279) Google Scholar), then not more than 5% of all pores in the mammalian rough ER have a Sec-like structure.What could be the function of the mammalian Sec61-62-63 complexes? Despite the clear differences between the cytosolic domains of this complex and the yeast Sec complex, one may speculate that the mammalian Sec61-62-63 may also perform post-translational protein translocation into the ER. However, so far no efficient post-translational translocation has been observed in mammals. Proteins that translocate post-translationally across yeast membranes in vitro, like the prepro-α-factor or the prepro-OmpA, do not do so across mammalian RM (46.Wiedmann M. Wiedmann B. Voigt S. Wachter E. Muller H.G. Rapoport T.A. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 1763-1768Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). The only natural substrates known to enter the mammalian ER after termination of their synthesis in a signal sequence-dependent manner are short membrane protein precursors such as M13 procoat (41.Watts C. Wickner W. Zimmermann R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1983; 80: 2809-2813Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar) or short precursors of hydrophobic secretory proteins like prepro-cecropin (42.Zimmermann R. Mollay C. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 12889-12895Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 43.Zimmermann R. Sagstetter M. Schlenstedt G. Biochimie (Paris). 1990; 72: 95-101Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). It has been suggested that these proteins may require membrane proteins for their translocation (42.Zimmermann R. Mollay C. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 12889-12895Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 44.Klappa P. Zimmermann M. Zimmermann R. FEBS Lett. 1994; 341: 281-387Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). However, it remains possible that their transport is independent of membrane components as has been found for M13 procoat in Escherichia coli (45.Wolfe P.B. Rice M. Wickner W. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 1836-1841Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).We were not able to identify Sec62 or Sec63 in association with ribosome-bound Sec61 complexes. However, this does not exclude that the Sec61-Sec62-Sec63 complexes translocate nascent polypeptide chains that are in the process of being synthesized by ribosomes not tightly bound to the translocation site. Another possibility is that the Sec61-Sec62-Sec63 complex performs the backward transport of ER proteins that are subject to the ubiquitin-proteasome-dependent degradation pathway as it has been suggested for the yeast Sec complex (32.Pilon M. Schekman R. Römisch K. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 4540-4548Crossref PubMed Scopus (345) Google Scholar, 33.Plemper R.K. Bohmler S. Bordallo J. Sommer T. Wolf D.H. Jungnickel B. Kutay U. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1996; 65: 271-303Crossref PubMed Scopus (492) Google Scholar). These proteins, Sec62 and Sec63, display homology to the yeast proteins Sec62p and Sec63p, respectively. Remarkably, for both proteins, regions with significant homology were those exposed to the ER lumen or located close to the cytosolic surface of the membrane. The more distal cytosolic parts were very divergent. While this manuscript was in preparation, Skowronek et al.(40.Skowronek M.H. Rotter M. Haas I. Biol. Chem. Regardless of the detergent used, and whether the purification started with RM or with PK-RM, only about 5% of Sec61 and about 30% of Sec63 were found in a complex. In each case the molar ratio between Sec61α and Sec63 in the complex appeared to be 1:1 to 1:2. The binding of Sec63 to the complex was stable, whereas the association of Sec62 with this complex was much weaker. Under optimized purification conditions, we found about 15% of the Sec62 co-purified with Sec61β. However, in the cross-linking experiment 30% of the Sec62 was linked to Sec61β. In the same samples less than 5% of the Sec61β was in proximity to Sec62, similar to that found with Sec63. Therefore the amount of Sec62 and Sec63 in these complexes was likely to be the same. If one assumes that 3 to 4 pentameric Sec61-Sec62-Sec63 units form a translocation pore as it has been shown for the trimeric complex (5.Hanein D. Matlack K.E. Jungnickel B. Plath K. Kalies K.U. Miller K.R. Rapoport T.A. Akey C.W. Cell. 1996; 87: 721-732Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (279) Google Scholar), then not more than 5% of all pores in the mammalian rough ER have a Sec-like structure. What could be the function of the mammalian Sec61-62-63 complexes? Despite the clear differences between the cytosolic domains of this complex and the yeast Sec complex, one may speculate that the mammalian Sec61-62-63 may also perform post-translational protein translocation into the ER. However, so far no efficient post-translational translocation has been observed in mammals. Proteins that translocate post-translationally across yeast membranes in vitro, like the prepro-α-factor or the prepro-OmpA, do not do so across mammalian RM (46.Wiedmann M. Wiedmann B. Voigt S. Wachter E. Muller H.G. Rapoport T.A. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 1763-1768Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). The only natural substrates known to enter the mammalian ER after termination of their synthesis in a signal sequence-dependent manner are short membrane protein precursors such as M13 procoat (41.Watts C. Wickner W. Zimmermann R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1983; 80: 2809-2813Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar) or short precursors of hydrophobic secretory proteins like prepro-cecropin (42.Zimmermann R. Mollay C. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 12889-12895Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 43.Zimmermann R. Sagstetter M. Schlenstedt G. Biochimie (Paris). 1990; 72: 95-101Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). It has been suggested that these proteins may require membrane proteins for their translocation (42.Zimmermann R. Mollay C. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 12889-12895Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 44.Klappa P. Zimmermann M. Zimmermann R. FEBS Lett. 1994; 341: 281-387Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). However, it remains possible that their transport is independent of membrane components as has been found for M13 procoat in Escherichia coli (45.Wolfe P.B. Rice M. Wickner W. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 1836-1841Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We were not able to identify Sec62 or Sec63 in association with ribosome-bound Sec61 complexes. However, this does not exclude that the Sec61-Sec62-Sec63 complexes translocate nascent polypeptide chains that are in the process of being synthesized by ribosomes not tightly bound to the translocation site. Another possibility is that the Sec61-Sec62-Sec63 complex performs the backward transport of ER proteins that are subject to the ubiquitin-proteasome-dependent degradation pathway as it has been suggested for the yeast Sec complex (32.Pilon M. Schekman R. Römisch K. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 4540-4548Crossref PubMed Scopus (345) Google Scholar, 33.Plemper R.K. Bohmler S. Bordallo J. Sommer T. Wolf D.H. Nature. 1997; 388: 891-895Crossref PubMed Scopus (469) Google Scholar, 34.Brodsky J.L. Werner E.D. Dubas M.E. Goeckeler J.L. Kruse K.B. McCracken A.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 3453-3460Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (231) Google Scholar). One should bear in mind that the majority of the Sec62 and the Sec63 were not found to be complexed. These populations could represent a pool that under appropriate conditions form Sec61-Sec62-Sec63 complexes. Alternatively, these molecules may perform functions while loosely associated with a subset of co-translational translocation sites. For example, they could recruit BiP molecules to resting trimeric Sec61 complexes in order to seal the pores, in alignment with a previous suggestion (20.Hamman B.D. Hendershot L.M. Johnson A.E. Cell. 1998; 92: 747-758Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar). They may also assist in the release of the translocational pausing of polypeptides such as the apolipoprotein B (47.Chuck S.L. Yao Z. Blackhart B.D. McCarthy B.J. Lingappa V.R. Nature. 1990; 346: 382-385Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar). The identification of a Sec-like complex in mammals again demonstrates the high degree of evolutionary conservation of the translocation machinery in the ER among eukaryotic organisms. However, the extent to which this structural similarity results in functional homology remains to be determined. We are indebted to T. A. Rapoport for generous support throughout the project. We also thank A. Wittstruck, B. Nentwig, and P. Schlotterhose for technical assistance; P. Henklein and W. Antonin for supplied material; and U. Platzer and C. D. Prescott for critical reading.

Studies of the structural organization of calcium/ calmodulin-dependent protein kinase IIα (CaM KIIα) and truncated CaM KIIα by three-dimensional electron microscopy and protein engineering show that the structures consist of 12 subunits that are organized in two stacked hexameric rings with 622 symmetry. The body of CaM KIIα is gear-shaped, consisting of six slanted flanges, and has six foot-like processes attached by narrow appendages to both ends of the flanges. Truncated CaM KIIα that lacks functional domains has a structure that is very similar to the body of CaM KIIα. Thus, the functional domains reside in the foot-like processes, and the association domain comprises the gear-shaped core. The ribbon diagram of the bilobate structure of CaM KI fits nicely in the envelope of the foot-like component and indicates that the crevice between the two lobes comprising the functional domains is near the middle portion of the foot. The clustering of the functional domains provides a favorable arrangement for the autophosphorylation reaction, and the unusual arrangement of the catalytic domain on extended tethers appears to be significant for the remarkable functional diversity of CaM KIIα in cellular regulation. The body of CaM KIIα is gear-shaped, consisting of six slanted flanges, and has six foot-like processes attached by narrow appendages to both ends of the flanges.
