A facultatively anaerobic alkaliphile,Exiguobacterium aurantiacum, possesses a P-type Na+-stimulated ATPase in the membrane (Koyama, N. (1999)Curr. Microbiol. 39, 27–30). In this study, we attempted to purify and characterize the enzyme. The ATPase appears to consist of a single polypeptide with an apparent molecular mass of 100 kDa. The enzyme exhibited an optimum pH for activity at around 9. The enzyme was strongly inhibited by vanadate (50% inhibition observed at 3 μm) and forms an acylphosphate intermediate, suggesting a P-type ATPase. The enzyme, when reconstituted into soybean phospholipid vesicles, exhibited ATP-dependent22Na+ uptake, which was completely inhibited by gramicidin. The reconstituted vesicles exhibited a generation of membrane potential (positive, inside). The enzyme is likely to be involved in an electrogenic transport of Na+. It has been suggested that a facultatively anaerobic alkaliphile BL77/1, a strain of Exiguobacterium aurantiacum, possesses a Na+-stimulated P-type ATPase in the membrane, which is expected to function as a sodium pump (20.Koyama N. Curr. Microbiol. 1999; 39: 27-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). In this study, purification and some characterization of the ATPase were attempted. The enzyme appears to consist of a single polypeptide with an apparent molecular mass of 100 kDa. The reconstituted vesicles of the enzyme exhibited a significant uptake of 22Na+. The enzyme is likely to be a P-type Na+-transport ATPase, which might be first identified in procaryotes (17.Dimroth P. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1318: 11-51Crossref PubMed Scopus (204) Google Scholar). E. aurantiacum BL77/1 was grown aerobically at 37 °C as described previously except that 0.5 m NaCl was added to the medium (20.Koyama N. Curr. Microbiol. 1999; 39: 27-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). The cells were collected at a late logarithmic phase, and the membranes were prepared according to the procedure described previously (6.Koyama N. Nosoh Y. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1985; 812: 206-212Crossref Scopus (35) Google Scholar, 21.Ohta K. Kiyomiya A. Koyama N. Nosoh Y. J. Gen. Microbiol. 1975; 86: 259-266Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). The freshly prepared membranes (about 60 mg of protein) were treated with 10 mm EDTA to remove loosely bound membrane proteins. After treatment, the membranes were suspended in 20 ml of a buffer containing 20 mmTris-HCl (pH 8), 200 mm KCl, and 1 mmMgCl2, and then 2.9 ml of 20 mm deoxy-BIGCHAP was added under magnetic stirring at 4 °C. To the supernatant obtained by the centrifugation for 20 min at 90,000 ×g, ammonium sulfate was added to 85% saturation. The floating precipitate was collected by centrifugation and then resolved in 0.5 ml of H2O. The sample thus obtained was applied on a Sepharose S-300 column (2 × 20 cm), which was equilibrated with a buffer (pH 8) containing 20 mm Tris, 20% ammonium sulfate, 1 mm MgCl2, 1 mm deoxy-BIGCHAP, and soybean lecithin (0.5 mg/ml), and then fractions of 1 ml were collected. Active fractions (14.Heise R. Müller V. Gottschalk G. Eur. J. Biochem. 1992; 206: 553-557Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar, 15.Smigan P. Majernik A. Polak P. Hapala I. Greksak M. Anaerobe. 1996; 2: 123-128Crossref Scopus (11) Google Scholar). Microbiol. 1999; 39: 27-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). Briefly, the purified enzyme (about 1 μg of protein) was incubated at 0 °C in a total volume of 50 μl of 20 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.2), 100 mm KCl, 100 mm NaCl, 1 mm MgCl2, and 1 mm β-mercaptoethanol. The reaction was initiated by the addition of 10 μm [γ-32P]ATP (111 TBq/mmol). After 60 s, the reaction was stopped by adding 50 μl of 10% trichloroacetic acid containing 1 mm sodium phosphate. The precipitated material was washed with water and then subjected to acidic lithium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (25.Dame J.B. Scarborough G.A. Biochemistry. 1980; 19: 2931-2937Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar) followed by autoradiography. Microbiol. 1999; 39: 27-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). Briefly, to 200 μl of Buffer A containing 1.6 mg of soybean lecithin, which was dissolved by sonication from a dried film deposited in the tube from an ether solution, was added 67 μl of 20 mm CHAPS. The suspension was mixed with 1 ml of the purified enzyme (about 6 μg), and then 160 mg of SM-2 Bio-Beads (Bio-Rad), which was previously washed by the procedure of Holloway (26.Holloway P.W. Anal. Biochem. 1973; 53: 304-308Crossref PubMed Scopus (641) Google Scholar), was added. After 30–60 min of a continuous stirring at room temperature, the turbid sample was applied instantly for the assay. The assay of22Na+ transport was conducted by the same procedure described previously (20.Koyama N. Curr. Microbiol. 1999; 39: 27-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). Membrane potential was measured by using Oxonol V at excitation and emission wavelengths of 595 and 640 nm, respectively, in a final volume of 2 ml of Buffer A containing 500 μl of the reconstituted sample. Protein concentration was determined by the Lowry assay (27.Lowry O.H. Rosebrough N.J. Farr A.L. Randall R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1951; 193: 265-275Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) using bovine serum albumin as standard. For the recovery of Na+-stimulated ATPase activity in a soluble fraction from the membranes, it was necessary to use detergent, suggesting that the enzyme is an integral membrane protein. Several detergents, such as Triton X-100, heptyl thioglucoside, polyoxyethylene 9-lauryl ether (C12E9), decanoyl N-methylglucamide,n-nonyl-β-d-thiomaltoside, sucrose monocaprate, sodium cholate, CHAPS, BIGCHAP, and deoxy-BIGCHAP were tested for the solubilization. Among them, deoxy-BIGCHAP and CHAPS were most effective. Because CHAPS, an ionic detergent, is inadequate to the application to ion-exchange chromatography for purification, a nonionic deoxy-BIGCHAP was used for solubilization. Fig. 1 A depicts the results of SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis at different stages of the purification procedure. A 100-kDa polypeptide appeared as a major band, although there are still some faint bands, the number of which varied from one preparation to the next. Incubation of the purified sample with [γ-32P]ATP demonstrated the existence of phosphorylated intermediate with a molecular mass of 100 kDa by acidic gel electrophoresis (Fig. 1 B, lane 1). Treatment of the labeled samples with 0.1 m Na2CO3and 0.25 m hydroxylamine, respectively, released the radioactive phosphates (lanes 2 and 3), indicating the acylphophate intermediate (28.Hugentobler G. Heid I. Solioz M. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 7611-7617Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). These results suggest that the purified enzyme is a P-type ATPase that consists of a single polypeptide with an apparent molecular mass of 100 kDa. The purified enzyme utilized ATP as the best substrate among the nucleotides tested. The rates of hydrolysis of CTP, ITP, dTTP, UTP, ADP and AMP relative to ATP were 8, 5, 5, 4, 0, and 0%, respectively. The enzyme is likely to hydrolyze only triphosphates of nucleosides. Fig. 2 depicts the effect of pH on the ATPase activity. The enzyme exhibited an optimum pH for activity at around 9. Fig. 3 depicts the concentration effect of vanadate on the ATPase activity. When vanadate concentration in the reaction medium was increased, ATPase activity was decreased sharply in the concentration range of 0.1–10 μm, and a half-maximal inhibition occurred at 3 μm, which was slightly higher than that of the membrane-bound ATPase (20.Koyama N. Curr. Microbiol. 1999; 39: 27-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (9) Google Scholar). The ATPase activity of the purified enzyme depended on NaCl concentration (Fig. 4). When measured in the presence of various concentration of NaCl, the activity was increased with increasing NaCl concentration, with near-saturation at around 100 mm. The reconstituted vesicles of enzyme exhibited a significant uptake of22Na+ when ATP was added, which was completely inhibited by gramicidin (Fig. 5). The ATP-dependent uptake of Na+ is likely to be accompanied with generation of an interior positive membrane potential, which was suggested by quenching of Oxonol V, a fluorescent dye, when NaCl was added (data not shown). Similarly to the ATPase activity, the initial rate of quenching was increased with increasing NaCl concentration (Fig. 4). The membrane potential could be dissipated by gramicidin, whereas the ATPase activity was accelerated about 3-fold by 10−7m gramicidin. Addition of LiCl, KCl, and RbCl caused essentially no quenching, suggesting that the quenching by NaCl is specific effect of Na+. These facts may indicate an electrogenic transport of Na+ by the enzyme. The result obtained in this study revealed that E. aurantiacum BL77/1 possesses a P-type Na+-transport ATPase. The growth medium of the bacterium contained approximately 0.5m Na+. When Na+ in the medium was replaced by K+, essentially no growth was observed. The bacterium exhibited Na+-dependent uptake of amino acids such as leucine and serine, 2N. Koyama, unpublished results. which suggests that Δμ̄Na+ is utilized as a driving force of active transport of the amino acids. The purified ATPase may contribute to the generation of Δμ̄Na+. Na+/K+-ATPase, a sodium pump in the plasma membrane of animal cells, is a typical P-type ATPase. In a preliminary experiment, the purified enzyme did not cross-react with an antiserum against porcine Na+/K+-ATPase. The enzyme might possess no common epitope with animal sodium pump. We are now attempting to isolate the structural gene of the enzyme for further characterization. We are grateful to Dr. Y. Hara, Tokyo Medical and Dental University School of Medicine, for a kind gift of an antiserum against porcine Na+/K+-ATPase.

C1 inhibitor, a plasma proteinase inhibitor of the serpin superfamily involved in the regulation of complement classical pathway and intrinsic blood coagulation, has been shown to bind to several components of the extracellular matrix. These reactions may be responsible for C1 inhibitor localization in the perivascular space. In the study reported here, we have examined whether C1 inhibitor could function as a substrate for plasma (factor XIIIa) or tissue transglutaminase. We made the following observations: 1) SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and autoradiography showed that C1 inhibitor exposed to tissue transglutaminase (but not to factor XIIIa) incorporated the radioactive amine donor substrate [3H]putrescine in a calcium-dependent manner; 2) the maximum stoichiometry for the uptake of [3H]putrescine by C1 inhibitor was 1:1; 3) proteolytic cleavage and peptide sequencing of reduced and carboxymethylated [3H]putrescine-C1 inhibitor identified Gln453(P′9) as the single amine acceptor residue; 4) studies with125I-labeled C1 inhibitor showed that tissue transglutaminase was also able to cross-link C1 inhibitor to immobilized fibrin; and 5) C1 inhibitor cross-linked by tissue transglutaminase to immobilized fibrin had inhibitory activity against its target enzymes. Thus, tissue transglutaminase-mediated cross-linking of C1 inhibitor to fibrin or other extracellular matrix components may serve as a mechanism for covalent serpin binding and influence local regulation of the proteolytic pathways inhibited by C1 inhibitor. Evans R.R. Am. J. Med. 1963; 35: 37-44Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (679) Google Scholar, 2.Agostoni A. Cicardi M. Medicine. 1992; 71: 206-215Crossref PubMed Scopus (561) Google Scholar). Like other serpins, C1 inhibitor inhibits its target proteinases by a suicide substrate mechanism that leads to the formation of inactive and covalent bimolecular serpin-enzyme complexes (3.Patston P.A. Gettins P. Beechem J. Schapira M. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 8876-8882Crossref PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar, 4.Gettins P. Patston P.A. Schapira M. BioEssays. 1993; 15: 461-467Crossref PubMed Scopus (96) Google Scholar, 5.Potempa J. Korzus E. Travis J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 15957-15960Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 6.Gils A. Declerck P. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1998; 80: 531-541Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). For C1 inhibitor, these target enzymes include serine proteinases of the complement classical pathway (C1r and C1s) and the blood coagulation intrinsic pathway/plasma kallikrein-kinin system (α- and β-factor XIIa, plasma kallikrein) (7.Davis III, A.E. Adv. Exp. Med. Biol. 1997; 425: 185-194Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). Thus, reduced levels of C1 inhibitor or the presence of a mutated dysfunctional serpin (as seen in type I and type II hereditary angioedema, respectively) lead to unregulated activation of these proteolytic pathways and increased production of the vasoactive mediator bradykinin (2.Agostoni A. Cicardi M. Medicine. 1992; 71: 206-215Crossref PubMed Scopus (561) Google Scholar, 7.Davis III, A.E. Adv. Exp. Med. Biol. 1997; 425: 185-194Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 8.Nussberger J. Cugno M. Amstutz C. Cicardi M. Pellacani A. Agostoni A. Lancet. 1998; 351: 1693-1697Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (639) Google Scholar). A particularity of hereditary angioedema attacks is that they have a marked tendency to be restricted to three specific sites, which include the subcutaneous space, the gut, and the upper airway (2.Agostoni A. Cicardi M. Medicine. 1992; 71: 206-215Crossref PubMed Scopus (561) Google Scholar, 9.Osler W. Am. J. Med. Sci. 1888; 95: 362-367Crossref Google Scholar). Thus, localized rather than systemic unregulated activation of C1 inhibitor-dependent proteolytic pathways with subsequent site-specific augmentation of vascular permeability is likely to be a key pathophysiologic event at the origin of hereditary angioedema attacks. Moreover, the focal pattern of vascular permeability changes seen during these attacks suggests a role for local concentrations of functional C1 inhibitor. Previous studies have shown that C1 inhibitor can bind to various ligands including heparin (10.Sim R.B. Arlaud G.J. Colomb M.G. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1980; 612: 433-439Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 11.Nilsson T. Wiman B. Eur. J. Biochem. 1983; 129: 663-667Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 12.Weiss V. Engel J. Commun. 1997; 230: 597-601Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar) and several components of the extracellular matrix, e.g. collagen IV, laminin, or entactin (15.Patston P.A. Schapira M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1997; 230: 597-601Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). However, although these reactions may provide a mechanism for C1 inhibitor localization in the perivascular space, it is likely that additional factors may also be involved. In the present study, we have examined whether C1 inhibitor could function as a substrate for plasma (factor XIIIa) or tissue transglutaminase, two enzymes that are abundant in the perivascular space where they have the ability of fortifying protein-protein interactions by catalyzing the formation of isopeptide bonds that are stable, covalent, and resistant to proteolysis (16.Greenberg C.S. Birckbichler P.J. Rice R.H. FASEB J. 1991; 5: 3071-3077Crossref PubMed Scopus (934) Google Scholar, 17.Aeschlimann D. Paulsson M. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1994; 71: 402-415Crossref PubMed Scopus (493) Google Scholar). High purity reagents were obtained from Sigma and Bio-Rad. [1,4-3H]Putrescine dihydrochloride (25 Ci/mmol), [125I]iodine (>16 Ci/mg of iodide) (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech), IODO-GEN™ precoated tubes and trifluoroacetic acid (Pierce), H-d-Phe-Pro-Arg-chloromethyl ketone (Bachem), acetonitrile hypergrade (Merck), and Ultima Gold™ scintillation liquid (Packard) were obtained from the designated suppliers. Methods Enzymol. 1988; 163: 179-185Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). Bovine serum albumin, guinea pig liver tissue transglutaminase, human IgG, α2-antiplasmin, thrombin and fibrinogen (Sigma), TPCK-treated trypsin (Worthington), sequencing grade chymotrypsin (Roche Molecular Biochemicals), human C1s and plasma kallikrein (Kordia), and factor XIII (American Diagnostica) were obtained from the designated suppliers. Tissue transglutaminase was dialyzed against 100 mm Tris, pH 8.3, containing 5 mm CaCl2 and 0.5 mm dithiothreitol before use. Human factor XIII was activated by human thrombin (0.5 NIH unit/mg of factor XIII) for 30 min at 37 °C; thrombin was then inhibited by adding 5 μmH-d-Phe-Pro-Arg-chloromethyl ketone. Discontinuous analytical SDS-PAGE1 was carried out using vertical slab gels according to Laemmli (19.Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685sCrossref PubMed Scopus (207123) Google Scholar). Samples were reduced before electrophoresis. Acrylamide concentrations were 4% in stacking gels and 7.5 or 15% in separating gels. Molecular weight standards were from Bio-Rad (broad range set for Coomassie Blue staining and kaleidoscope prestained set for autoradiography). Gels were either stained with Coomassie Blue or revealed by autoradiography. For autoradiography, [3H]putrescine-containing gels were soaked in Entensify™ (NEN Life Science Products) and dried;125I-containing gels were dried without prior treatment. Dried gels were exposed for autoradiography using X-Omat™ AR films (Eastman Kodak Co.) at −80 °C. Preparative SDS-PAGE was performed using a model 491 Prep Cell (Bio-Rad) according to the recommendations of the manufacturer. Acrylamide concentration was 4% in the stacking gel and 5% in the separating gel. [3H]Putrescine incorporation was carried out in 100 mm Tris, pH 8.3, containing 5 mm CaCl2 and 0.5 mmdithiothreitol. C1 inhibitor, bovine serum albumin, and human IgG (1.0 μm) were incubated with tissue transglutaminase (0.1 μm) in the presence of [3H]putrescine (1.0 μm). In experiments employing α2-antiplasmin (1 μm), the ratio between tissue transglutaminase and α2-antiplasmin was 1:20. C1 inhibitor and α2-antiplasmin (1 μm) were incubated with factor XIIIa in the presence of [3H]putrescine at a factor XIIIa/serpin ratio of 1:10 and 1:30, respectively. Samples with transglutaminase alone were prepared in the same way, but acceptor proteins were absent. For control experiments, samples were supplemented with 20 mm EDTA before the addition of transglutaminase. Unless otherwise indicated, reactions were carried out for 6 h at 37 °C and then stopped by adding SDS-PAGE sample buffer or trichloroacetic acid solution. Reaction products were analyzed by SDS-PAGE or liquid scintillation counting. Incorporation of [3H]putrescine into C1 inhibitor was performed as described above. For time course analyses, transglutamination was stopped at various times by trichloroacetic acid precipitation. For stoichiometry determination, reactions were carried out at 37 °C in the presence of a fixed concentration of [3H]putrescine (10 μm) and increasing concentrations of unlabeled putrescine. C1 inhibitor concentration was 10 μm, while tissue transglutaminase was 1.0 μm. After 6 h of incubation, reaction mixture aliquots were withdrawn, mixed with SDS-PAGE sample buffer, and submitted to SDS-PAGE followed by autoradiography. For quantitative analysis, autoradiograms were scanned using a Personal Densitometer equipped with ImageQuant 5.0 software (Molecular Dynamics, Inc., Sunnyvale, CA). Other reaction mixture aliquots were supplemented with 500 μg of bovine serum albumin in cold phosphate-buffered saline buffer and precipitated with 1 volume of cold aqueous 20% trichloroacetic acid. After vigorous mixing, these solutions were incubated overnight on ice. Trichloroacetic acid-precipitated proteins were then sedimented by centrifugation. After two washes with cold aqueous 10% trichloroacetic acid, pellets were dissolved in scintillation liquid and counted in a Packard Liquid Scintillation Analyzer 2500 TR. [3H]Putrescine-C1 inhibitor was prepared by incubating C1 inhibitor (35 μm) with tissue transglutaminase (4 μm) in the presence of [3H]putrescine (8 μm) at 37 °C. After a 3-h incubation, unlabeled putrescine (300 μm) was added, and incubation was continued for 3 h. After supplementation with guanidinium hydrochloride (final concentration 5.0 m) and dithiothreitol (final concentration 5 mm), reaction mixtures were incubated for 30 min at 37 °C. Following the addition of a neutral aqueous solution of iodoacetic acid (50 mm; 0.1 (v/v)), samples were further incubated for 30 min at 37 °C and reexposed to dithiothreitol and iodoacetic acid. After extensive dialysis against ammonium hydrogen carbonate (25 mm), samples were submitted to preparative SDS-PAGE. Fractions containing the 95-kDa [3H]putrescine-C1 inhibitor complex (as assessed by 7.5% analytical SDS-PAGE and autoradiography) were pooled, extensively dialyzed against 10 mm ammonium hydrogen carbonate, and freeze-dried. The solid material was dissolved into ammonium hydrogen carbonate (0.1 m) and digested with trypsin (1:100, w/w) overnight at 37 °C or with chymotrypsin (1:100, w/w) for 2 h at 37 °C. Tryptic and chymotryptic peptides were separated on a μRPC C2/C18 reverse phase column (2.1 × 10 mm) connected to a SMART system (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech), the solvents being 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (solvent A) and 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid in 80% acetonitrile (solvent B), and using a linear gradient (from 0 to 100%) of solvent B. Peptides were detected at 214 nm and collected for further analysis. One-tenth volume of each fraction was mixed with scintillation liquid and counted for 3H radioactivity. Tritiated tryptic and chymotryptic peptides were characterized by Edman degradation, amino acid analysis, mass determination, and localization within the known amino acid sequence of C1 inhibitor (20.Bock S.C. Skriver K. Nielsen E. Thogersen H.C. Wiman B. Donaldson V.H. Eddy R.L. Marrinan J. Radziejewska E. Huber R. Shows T.B. Magnusson S. Biochemistry. 1986; 25: 4292-4301Crossref PubMed Scopus (268) Google Scholar) at the Protein Analytical Service of the University of Berne, Switzerland. C1 inhibitor, α2-antiplasmin, plasma kallikrein, and C1s (50 μg) were radiolabeled with 125I using the IODO-GEN method (Pierce) according to the recommendations of the manufacturer. Specific radioactivities of iodinated proteins ranged from 3.0 to 5.0 mCi/mg. A modification of the method of Valnickova and Enghild was employed (21.Valnickova Z. Enghild J.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 27220-27224Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar). Immobilized fibrin was prepared by incubating 100 μl of 500 μg/ml fibrinogen in 20 mm Tris, 137 mm NaCl, pH 7.6 (TBS buffer) with 10 μl of human thrombin (5 NIH units/ml) for 1.0 h at 37 °C in MaxiSorb™ polystyrene tubes (Nunc). The fibrin gel was then dried overnight at 45 °C in a ventilated oven. Thereafter, the tubes were blocked for 5 h at 37 °C with 1 ml of bovine serum albumin (1%) in TBS buffer and washed three times with TBS buffer containing 10 mm CaCl2 and 0.5 mmdithiothreitol (buffer A). Cross-linking was performed by incubating125I-C1 inhibitor (0.2 μg) or125I-α2-antiplasmin (0.2 μg) overnight at 37 °C with increasing amount of tissue transglutaminase in 50 μl of buffer A. After four washes with 1 ml of TBS buffer containing 0.5% SDS, the tubes were counted for 125I radioactivity. For control experiments, CaCl2 in buffer A was replaced by EDTA. C1 inhibitor crossed-linked to fibrin was prepared as described above using unlabeled C1 inhibitor and 0.25 μg of tissue transglutaminase. After the last wash with TBS, 0.5% SDS, the tubes were washed three times with 1 ml of TBS buffer containing 0.1% Tween 20 and three times with TBS buffer alone. Binding studies were performed using 125I-plasma kallikrein or125I-C1s in 40 μl of TBS buffer. Test tubes were incubated overnight at 37 °C, washed four times with 1 ml of TBS buffer containing 0.5% SDS and then counted for 125I radioactivity. Binding experiments were also carried out using PMSF-inactivated 125I-plasma kallikrein or125I-C1s. Inactivation of 125I-plasma kallikrein or 125I-C1s by PMSF was verified by demonstrating that radiolabeled PMSF-treated serine proteinases did not form covalent bimolecular enzyme-serpin complexes with C1 inhibitor, as assessed by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography. The hypothesis that C1 inhibitor could function as a substrate for tissue transglutaminase or factor XIIIa was examined in experiments evaluating tissue transglutaminase-mediated and factor XIIIa-mediated incorporation of radiolabeled [3H]putrescine into this serpin. α2-Antiplasmin, a serpin that is a well characterized amine acceptor substrate (22.Tamaki T. Aoki N. J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 257: 14767-14772Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), was used as a positive control. Reaction mixtures resulting from serpin incubation with [3H]putrescine in the presence of each transglutaminase were separated by SDS-PAGE and analyzed by Coomassie Blue staining and autoradiography. Under reducing conditions, C1 inhibitor had an apparent molecular mass of 95 kDa (Fig.1 A, lanes 1 and 5) and α2-antiplasmin of 65 kDa (Fig. 1 A, lanes 3 and7). Autoradiographic analysis showed, as expected, that tissue transglutaminase and factor XIIIa catalyzed the incorporation of [3H]putrescine into α2-antiplasmin (Fig.1 B, lanes 3 and 7). The pattern seen with C1 inhibitor was different, since incorporation of [3H]putrescine into this serpin was observed with tissue transglutaminase but not with factor XIIIa (Fig. 1 B,lanes 1 and 5). Several samples, in particular those treated with tissue transglutaminase, contained high molecular weight radioactive bands at the border between the stacking and separating gels (see, for example, Fig. 1 B,lanes 1 and 3). These bands, which were also seen, although more faintly, when tissue transglutaminase was incubated with [3H]putrescine in the absence of acceptor serpin (Fig. 1 B, lanes 2 and4), probably reflected the formation of homo- or heteropolymers involving tissue transglutaminase and C1 inhibitor. Additional experiments were conducted to assess the specificity of the reaction between tissue transglutaminase and C1 inhibitor (Fig.2). Consistent with the notion that tissue transglutaminase requires the presence of calcium ions for expressing catalytic activity (17.Aeschlimann D. Paulsson M. Thromb. Haemostasis. 1994; 71: 402-415Crossref PubMed Scopus (493) Google Scholar), EDTA completely prevented tissue transglutaminase-mediated incorporation of [3H]putrescine into C1 inhibitor (Fig. 2 B, lane 3). Moreover, exposure to [3H]putrescine and tissue transglutaminase of bovine serum albumin (Fig. 2 A,lane 4) or human IgG (Fig. 2 A,lane 5), two proteins that have not been reported to contain amine acceptor sites, was not accompanied by radioactive amine incorporation (Fig. 2 B, lanes 4and 5).Figure 2SDS-PAGE analysis (7.5%, reduced) of tissue transglutaminase-mediated [3H]putrescine incorporation into C1 inhibitor, bovine serum albumin, or human IgG. A time course analysis of tissue transglutaminase-catalyzed [3H]putrescine incorporation into C1 inhibitor showed maximal uptake of the radioactive amine after 4–6 h of incubation at 37 °C (data not illustrated). The number of acceptor sites in C1 inhibitor was determined by experiments in which tissue transglutaminase-mediated cross-linking of [3H]putrescine to C1 inhibitor was performed under saturation conditions. These experiments were done in the presence of a constant amount of [3H]putrescine and increasing amounts of unlabeled putrescine. After 6 h of incubation at 37 °C, an aliquot of each sample was collected for SDS-PAGE analysis, while the rest of the material was precipitated with trichloroacetic acid and counted for 3H radioactivity. Correction factor F, the fraction of [3H]putrescine associated with C1 inhibitor at 95 kDa was determined by densitometric analysis of SDS-PAGE autoradiograms. The stoichiometry of the reaction between amine and serpin was derived from total radioactivity measurements in trichloroacetic acid precipitates and correction factor F. As shown in Fig. 3, 1 mol of C1 inhibitor incorporated approximately 1 mol of [3H]putrescine when saturating concentrations of putrescine were used, an observation indicating that C1 inhibitor contains a single amine acceptor site. The modified radiolabeled serpin, a single component of 95 kDa as assessed by analytical SDS-PAGE and autoradiography, was subjected to tryptic or chymotryptic digestion. Two major radioactive peptides were obtained upon reverse phase HPLC elution of the tryptic digest (Fig.4 A). These peptides were characterized by determination of the amino-terminal 5 residues (by the Edman degradation) and mass spectroscopy. The first radioactive peptide corresponded to Thr445–Ala478 of C1 inhibitor (20.Bock S.C. Skriver K. Nielsen E. Thogersen H.C. Wiman B. Donaldson V.H. Eddy R.L. Marrinan J. Radziejewska E. Huber R. Shows T.B. Magnusson S. Biochemistry. 1986; 25: 4292-4301Crossref PubMed Scopus (268) Google Scholar) and the second to Thr445–Arg472. Thus, the site of incorporation of [3H]putrescine was localized in the C-terminal domain of C1 inhibitor, a protein loop released from the serpin upon cleavage of the P1-P′1(Arg444-Thr445) reactive site peptide bond. Four glutamine residues (Gln452, Gln453, Gln462, and Gln463) are present in these two peptides and constitute potential sites for [3H]putrescine incorporation. The elution profile of modified C1 inhibitor chymotryptic digest displayed a single radioactive peak (Fig. 4 B), which was isolated upon rechromatography (Fig. 4 C). This peak was formed by the tripeptide X-Pro-Phe, as assessed by Edman degradation and amino acid analysis. Liquid scintillation counting of the successive degradation cycles yielded a mean value of 33,103 cpm for the first cycle, while mean values for the next two cycles were 3615 and 1552 cpm, respectively. It was concluded that X was formed by [3H]putrescine covalently bound to Gln453, since Gln453 is the only Gln in C1 inhibitor that is followed by Pro and Phe. This observation that Gln453 can function as an amine acceptor site implies that its side chain is exposed at the surface of C1 inhibitor, where it can be accessible to covalent modification. Two cleavages are detectable during the early phase of C1 inhibitor proteolysis by bovine pancreatic trypsin. The first cleavage takes place at P1 and generates a major fragment (444 residues with Arg444 at the new carboxyl terminus) termed here I′ and a minor fragment (34 residues with Thr445 at the new amino terminus) (25.Harpel P.C. Autoradiographic analysis showed that the radioactive label, which migrated at the front of the gel when the acrylamide concentration in the separating gel was 7.5% (Fig. 5 B), was associated with a component having an apparent molecular mass of 3.9 kDa when the acrylamide concentration was increased to 15% (Fig. 5 C). This result provides a confirmation that the site where [3H]putrescine is cross-linked by tissue transglutaminase is located within the Thr445–Ala478 C-terminal domain of C1 inhibitor. The possibility that C1 inhibitor could be cross-linked to a lysine donor protein via a transglutaminase-mediated reaction was examined by studying the effect of various concentrations of tissue transglutaminase on 125I-C1 inhibitor or125I-α2-antiplasmin covalent binding to an immobilized fibrin film. Both 125I-C1 inhibitor and125I-α2-antiplasmin were cross-linked to immobilized fibrin by tissue transglutaminase in a calcium-dependent reaction (Fig.6). Radiolabeled serpin binding to fibrin was dependent of the concentration of tissue transglutaminase, and it was comparable for 125I-C1 inhibitor and125I-α2-antiplasmin. However, when the specific radioactivities of the two serpins were taken into account, it appeared that the amount of 125I-C1 inhibitor bound to the immobilized fibrin gel was about 4 times lower than that of125I-α2-antiplasmin. Additional experiments were designed to assess whether C1 inhibitor cross-linked to fibrin retained inhibitory activity against its target serine proteinases, as assessed by the formation of covalent and immobilized bimolecular complexes between serpins and their target serine proteinases. As shown in Table I, C1 inhibitor cross-linked to fibrin was very efficient in covalently binding catalytically active125I-plasma kallikrein or 125I-C1s. In contrast, binding of these two proteinases was dramatically decreased in experiments employing plasma kallikrein or C1s that had been inactivated by PMSF to form active site-blocked phenylmethanesulfonyl-125I-kallikrein or -C1s. Furthermore,125I-plasma kallikrein and 125I-C1s covalent binding was also nearly abolished in control experiments where tissue transglutaminase-mediated C1 inhibitor cross-linking to immobilized fibrin was prevented by EDTA, demonstrating absent direct firm attachment of these serine proteinases to a fibrin matrix.Table IBinding of radioiodinated plasma kallikrein or C1s to C1 inhibitor cross-linked to fibrinSurfaceC1 inhibitor cross-linked to fibrinControlcpm125I-Kallikrein128,930 ± 93205562 ± 2263125I-Kallikrein treated with PMSF1726 ± 318492 ± 115125I-C1s32,073 ± 53493671 ± 1917125I-C1s treated with PMSF8764 ± 25101882 ± 333Values are mean ± S.D. Binding of active or PMSF-treated 125I-plasma kallikrein or 125I-C1s was determined after 4 h of incubation at 37 °C. For control experiments, C1 inhibitor cross-linking to fibrin was prevented by EDTA. The results of this study demonstrate that C1 inhibitor is a substrate for tissue transglutaminase and that C1 inhibitor cross-linked to a fibrin matrix retains inhibitory activity against its target serine proteinases C1s and plasma kallikrein. However, several issues need to be addressed before one can understand the full biological implication of this observation. Histochemical studies will be required to assess whether C1 inhibitor is present in a cross-linked form in certain perivascular regions and to identify the components with which this serpin might be associated. If it is observed that C1 inhibitor can be cross-linked in vivo, experiments will have to be designed to establish whether this reaction takes place as a part of matrix normal make up or as a response to some challenge such as the inflammatory reaction. In addition, the impact of being cross-linked to a lysine donor protein such as fibrin on C1 inhibitor inhibitory specificity and reactivity needs to be examined in detailed kinetic studies. The study reported here has shown that C1 inhibitor cross-linked to immobilized fibrin can inhibit C1s and plasma kallikrein; however, this study has not determined whether cross-linked C1 inhibitor is more, equally, or less efficient in inhibiting these serine proteinases than the free serpin or whether the cross-linking reaction modifies the inhibitory specificity. If cross-linked C1 inhibitor is equally active or more active than the native form against its target enzymes, this would suggest that transglutaminase-mediated cross-linking of C1 inhibitor to matrix components provides a critical mechanism for the local control of vascular permeability. Importantly, if this scenario is operative in vivo, then diminished perivascular C1 inhibitor cross-linking (e.g. because of mutation of C1 inhibitor Gln453 or altered tissue transglutaminase binding or activity) could represent a hitherto unrecognized pathophysiological mechanism in certain cases of hereditary angioedema. However, it could also be possible that cross-linked C1 inhibitor is less active against its target serine proteinases than the free serpin, i.e. that serpin transglutamination reduces and/or modifies its inhibitory activity. If that is the case, then cross-linking of C1 inhibitor to extracellular matrix components could lead to reduced inhibition of the serine proteinases of complement classical pathway and intrinsic blood coagulation/plasma kallikrein-kinin system and therefore to increased bradykinin production with subsequent increase of vascular permeability.

Megalin/low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 2 (LRP-2) is an endocytic receptor expressed in highly specialized cell types such as parathyroid cells and epithelia of the kidney. Previous experiments identified a nonconsensus TATA element, with the sequence TAGAAAA, as crucial for accurate and efficient transcription from the LRP-2 promoter. Here we show that, in addition to the TAGA element, promoter sequences downstream of the transcription start site contribute significantly to transcription both in vitro and in transfected cells. Deletion and point mutational analyses reveal that the promoter region located between positions +5 and +11 (sequence TTTTGGC) is of particular importance. Complementation experiments in nuclear extracts lacking transcription factor IID (TFIID) activity show that TATA-binding protein-associated factors of TFIID are essential for the function of LRP-2 downstream promoter sequences. Interestingly, DNase I footprinting studies show that the downstream region between positions +5 and +11 does not significantly affect overall TFIID affinity to the promoter but that it profoundly affects the topology of the TFIID·promoter complex not only downstream of the transcription start site, but in particular in the TATA box region. Our observations suggest a model for a novel downstream sequence function, in which TATA-binding protein-associated factor-promoter interactions downstream of the transcription start site modulate TFIID-DNA interactions in the TATA box region. Previous experiments identified a nonconsensus TATA element, with the sequence TAGAAAA, as crucial for accurate and efficient transcription from the LRP-2 promoter. Here we show that, in addition to the TAGA element, promoter sequences downstream of the transcription start site contribute significantly to transcription both in vitro and in transfected cells. Deletion and point mutational analyses reveal that the promoter region located between positions +5 and +11 (sequence TTTTGGC) is of particular importance. Complementation experiments in nuclear extracts lacking transcription factor IID (TFIID) activity show that TATA-binding protein-associated factors of TFIID are essential for the function of LRP-2 downstream promoter sequences. Interestingly, DNase I footprinting studies show that the downstream region between positions +5 and +11 does not significantly affect overall TFIID affinity to the promoter but that it profoundly affects the topology of the TFIID·promoter complex not only downstream of the transcription start site, but in particular in the TATA box region. Our observations suggest a model for a novel downstream sequence function, in which TATA-binding protein-associated factor-promoter interactions downstream of the transcription start site modulate TFIID-DNA interactions in the TATA box region. transcription factors IIA–H, respectively initiator downstream promoter element TATA-binding protein TBP-associated factor low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 2 hexahistidine-tagged TBP FLAG epitope-tagged TFIID HeLa nuclear extract lacking TBP and TAFIIs The process of transcription underlies strong regulatory mechanisms, restricting expression of most genes to certain cell types or developmental stages. The establishment of cell-free systems, some 20 years ago, has permitted biochemical fractionation and purification of a set of six general transcription factors, denoted TFIIA,1 -B, -D, -E, -F, and -H, that, in addition to RNA polymerase II, are minimally required for low (basal) levels of accurate transcription initiation in vitro. The activity of the general transcription machineryin vivo is regulated by gene- and cell type-specific transcription activators and repressors as well as various cofactors that are thought to function as mediators between regulatory proteins and individual components of the general transcription machinery (reviewed in Refs. 1.Roeder R.G. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1996; 21: 327-335Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (718) Google Scholar and 2.Orphanides G. Lagrange T. Reinberg D. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 2657-2683Crossref PubMed Scopus (851) Google Scholar). A key step in the formation of functional transcription initiation complexes is the recognition of promoter sequences by components of the general transcription machinery. Indeed, it has become evident that the core promoter sequence context has a significant influence on both the overall efficiency of gene transcription and the ability of individual genes to respond to various transcription activators (1.Roeder R.G. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1996; 21: 327-335Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (718) Google Scholar, 3.Verrijzer C.P. Tjian R. Trends Biochem Sci. 1996; 21: 338-342Crossref PubMed Scopus (319) Google Scholar). Functional core promoter sequence elements identified to date include the TATA box, the initiator (Inr), the downstream promoter element (DPE), and the TFIIB recognition element. The best characterized core promoter elements are the TATA box, an A/T-rich sequence located about 25–30 nucleotides upstream of the transcription start site that is recognized by the TATA-binding subunit of TFIID (reviewed in Ref. 4.Burley S.K. Roeder R.G. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1996; 65: 769-799Crossref PubMed Scopus (628) Google Scholar), and the Inr element, a pyrimidine-rich sequence with the consensus YYA+1N(T/A)YY at the start site of transcription (5.Smale S.T. Baltimore D. Cell. 1989; 57: 103-113Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1150) Google Scholar, 6.Javahery R. Khachi A. Lo K. Zenzie-Gregory B. Smale S.T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 116-127Crossref PubMed Scopus (596) Google Scholar). Both TATA and Inr elements are sufficient to independently direct accurate transcription initiation in vitro but can also function in concert in a synergistic manner (see Ref. 7.Martinez E. Chiang C.M. Ge H. Roeder R.G. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 3115-3126Crossref PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar and references therein). The DPE was recently identified as a sequence element in many TATA-less, Inr-containing promoters, located some 25–30 nucleotides downstream of the transcription start site with the consensus (A/G)G(A/T)CGTG (8.Burke T.W. Kadonaga J.T. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 711-724Crossref PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar, 9.Burke T.W. Kadonaga J.T. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 3020-3031Crossref PubMed Scopus (399) Google Scholar). Finally, the TFIIB recognition element was identified, by binding site selection, as a GC-rich sequence located immediately upstream of the TATA box, which can enhance both binding of TFIIB to the TBP·DNA complex and promoter activity (10.Lagrange T. Kapanidis A.N. Tang H. Reinberg D. Ebright R.H. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 34-44Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar). While the functions of the TATA box and the TFIIB recognition element sequences correlate well with their relative affinities to their cognate binding proteins TBP and TFIIB (10.Lagrange T. Kapanidis A.N. Tang H. Reinberg D. Ebright R.H. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 34-44Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar, 11.Wobbe C.R. Struhl K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 3859-3867Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar), studies in cell-free metazoan systems (7.Martinez E. Chiang C.M. Ge H. Roeder R.G. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 3115-3126Crossref PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar, 12.Kaufmann J. Smale S.T. Genes Dev. 1994; 8: 821-829Crossref PubMed Scopus (216) Google Scholar, 13.Verrijzer C.P. Chen J.L. Yokomori K. Tjian R. Cell. 1995; 81: 1115-1125Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (257) Google Scholar) and studies in yeast cells (14.Moqtaderi Z. Bai Y. Poon D. Weil P.A. Struhl K. Nature. 1996; 383: 188-191Crossref PubMed Scopus (251) Google Scholar, 15.Shen W.C. Green M.R. Cell. 1997; 90: 615-624Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar) have established a general requirement for TAFIIs in the function of promoter regions downstream of the TATA element as well as for the transcription of TATA-less genes (7.Martinez E. Chiang C.M. Ge H. Roeder R.G. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 3115-3126Crossref PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar) where the TATA box-binding activity of TBP is largely dispensable (16.Martinez E. Zhou Q. L'Etoile N.D. Oelgeschläger T. Berk A.J. Roeder R.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 11864-11868Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). More specifically, functional studies with partially reconstituted recombinantDrosophila TFIID complexes have shown a minimal requirement of TBP, TAFII250, and TAFII150 for promoter-specific downstream sequence function (13.Verrijzer C.P. Chen J.L. Yokomori K. Tjian R. Cell. 1995; 81: 1115-1125Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (257) Google Scholar). DNase I footprinting studies had demonstrated earlier that the human TFIID multiprotein complex, but not TBP alone, can make contact with promoter sequences downstream of the TATA element and the transcription start site of certain core promoter sequences (17.Nakajima N. Horikoshi M. Roeder R.G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1988; 8: 4028-4040Crossref PubMed Scopus (297) Google Scholar, 18.Nakatani Y. Horikoshi M. Brenner M. Yamamoto T. Besnard F. Roeder R.G. Freese E. Nature. 1990; 348: 86-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar, 19.Chiang C.M. Ge H. Wang Z. Hoffmann A. Roeder R.G. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 2749-2762Crossref PubMed Scopus (171) Google Scholar). More recently, UV cross-linking experiments have examined the relative disposition of DNA and TFIID subunits within a human TFIID·promoter complex and have identified several human and Drosophila TFIID subunits in close proximity of promoter DNA. These studies suggest thatDrosophila and human TAFII250 and TAFII150 might directly interact with the Inr element and promoter regions downstream of certain promoters (13.Verrijzer C.P. Chen J.L. Yokomori K. Tjian R. Cell. 1995; 81: 1115-1125Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (257) Google Scholar, 20.Verrijzer C.P. Yokomori K. Chen J.L. Tjian R. Science. 1994; 264: 933-941Crossref PubMed Scopus (178) Google Scholar, 21.Oelgeschläger T. Chiang C.M. Roeder R.G. Nature. 1996; 382: 735-738Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar) and that the histone-like Drosophila TFIID subunits TAFII60 and TAFII40 may contact the DPE (9.Burke T.W. Kadonaga J.T. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 3020-3031Crossref PubMed Scopus (399) Google Scholar). Based on these observations, it has been proposed that downstream promoter elements function in part by increasing TFIID·promoter complex formation and/or stability through direct interactions with TAFIIs. Furthermore, dependent on the presence of TFIIA, TAFII interactions with downstream promoter regions may be concomitant with the formation of a stereospecific TFIID·promoter complex (21.Oelgeschläger T. Chiang C.M. Roeder R.G. Nature. 1996; 382: 735-738Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar), consistent with a general requirement for TFIIA in core promoter- and TAFII-dependent transcription (22.Hansen S.K. Tjian R. Cell. 1995; 82: 565-575Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, 23.Emami K.H. Jain A. Smale S.T. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 3007-3019Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar, 24.Martinez E. Ge H. Tao Y. Yuan C.X. Palhan V. Roeder R.G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 6571-6583Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Finally, a recent study has identified novel TAFII- and initiator-dependent cofactors (TICs) that are, in addition to TFIIA and TAFIIs, required for core promoter-specific functions of TFIID through the initiator region of TATA-containing and TATA-less promoters (24.Martinez E. Ge H. Tao Y. Yuan C.X. Palhan V. Roeder R.G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 6571-6583Crossref PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Taken together, these observations suggest that quantitative or qualitative core promoter sequence-dependent effects on TFIID promoter binding may constitute one important step for the functional readout of downstream core promoter sequence elements. We previously identified a weak, atypical TATA box (TAGAAAA) as necessary for transcription of the human megalin/low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 2 (LRP-2) gene promoter (25.Knutson A. Hellman P. Akerstrom G. Westin G. DNA Cell Biol. 1998; 17: 551-560Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). Here, we demonstrate that efficient LRP-2 transcription additionally requires promoter sequences downstream of the transcription start site. Deletion and point mutation analyses indicate that stimulatory LRP-2 downstream promoter functions are conferred to a large extent by core promoter sequences located between positions +5 and +11, with no apparent sequence similarities to the Inr and DPE consensus sequences. DNase I footprinting experiments reveal that the presence of this sequence does not significantly affect the overall affinity of TFIID binding. Instead, TFIID interactions with the +5 to +11 region induce dramatic qualitative changes in TFIID interactions in the LRP-2 TATA box region, suggesting the formation of a conformationally distinct TFIID·promoter complex. A previously described fragment of the human LRP-2 promoter, containing sequences between positions −120 and +52, cloned into the pGL-3 basic vector (25.Knutson A. Hellman P. Akerstrom G. Westin G. We have shown previously that LRP-2 promoter activity is dependent on a weak nonconsensus TATA element with the sequence TAGAAAA located 30 bp upstream of the transcription initiation site (25.Knutson A. Hellman P. Akerstrom G. Westin G. DNA Cell Biol. 1998; 17: 551-560Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). Earlier studies demonstrated that introduction of a G·C base pair at position 3 of the TATAAAA consensus sequence reduces TFIID promoter activity 50-fold (11.Wobbe C.R. Struhl K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 3859-3867Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar). We therefore reasoned that additional core promoter sequences downstream of the TATA element may contribute to the LRP-2 promoter activity. Since the LRP-2 promoter appears to lack an initiator element (consensus YYA+1N(T/A)YY; Ref. 6.Javahery R. Khachi A. Lo K. Zenzie-Gregory B. Smale S.T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 116-127Crossref PubMed Scopus (596) Google Scholar), we examined the functional contribution of LRP-2 promoter sequences downstream of the transcription start site. Two 3′-deletion LRP-2 promoter mutants, encompassing nucleotides −120 to +11 and −120 to +4 (Fig. 1 A), were constructed, and their transcription activities were compared with that of the full-length promoter (−120/+52; Ref. 25.Knutson A. Hellman P. Akerstrom G. Westin G. DNA Cell Biol. 1998; 17: 551-560Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar) in vitro and in transfected cells. As shown in Fig. 1 B, RNA polymerase II-dependent LRP-2 transcription (compare lanes 1 and2) was moderately reduced by deletion of the promoter region between +11 and +52 (compare lanes 1 and3). Further deletion of sequences to +4, however, resulted in a dramatic reduction of LRP-2 promoter activity, almost to background level (Fig. 1 B, compare lanes 3 and 4). Importantly, introduction of clustered point mutations between +5 and +11 in constructs carrying LRP-2 promoter sequences either from −120 to +52 (yielding −120/+52 mut(4–10)) or from −120/+11 (yielding −120/+11 mut(5–8); Fig.1 A) also strongly reduced LRP-2 promoter activity (Fig.1 B, compare lane 1 withlane 5, and compare lane 3with lane 6). These observations demonstrate that core promoter sequences downstream of the transcription start site significantly contribute to efficient LRP-2 transcription in HeLa nuclear extracts and that a major proportion of LRP-2 downstream promoter function is conferred by the DNA sequence 5′-TTTTGGC-3′ located between +5 and +11. To study the function of LRP-2 downstream promoter regions in living cells, we co-transfected JEG-3 cells, which express LRP-2, with reporter plasmids containing the LRP-2 promoter variants fused to a luciferase reporter gene (Fig. 1 A) and a β-galactosidase reference plasmid. As shown in Fig. 1 C, deletion of LRP-2 promoter sequences from +11 to +52 reduced luciferase activities in the respective cell extracts by 50%, while further deletion of sequences from +11 to +4 resulted in an additional 2–3-fold reduction of LRP-2 promoter activity. Importantly, and in agreement with our in vitro data, clustered point mutation of promoter sequences between +5 and +11 affected LRP-2 transcription to the same extent as the deletion of promoter sequences between +5 and +11 (Fig. 1 C). We confirmed that changes in luciferase activity in these assays indeed reflected changes in intracellular luciferase mRNA levels by performing RNase protection assays (Fig. 1 D) on total RNA from cells co-transfected with derivatives of our luciferase reporter gene constructs carrying the SV40 enhancer upstream of the LRP-2 promoter and the OVEC-REF plasmid as a reference (28.Westin G. Gerster T. Muller M.M. Schaffner G. Schaffner W. Nucleic Acids Res. 1987; 15: 6787-6798Crossref PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar). Taken together, these findings demonstrate a requirement of core promoter sequences downstream of the transcription start site for efficient LRP-2 transcription in vitro and in transfected cells. Our data also suggest that a major proportion of LRP-2 downstream promoter function is conferred by the DNA sequence 5′-TTTTGGC-3′ located between positions +5 and +11. This sequence appears not to be related to a functional initiator element (consensus YYA+1N(T/A)YY; Ref. 6.Javahery R. Khachi A. Lo K. Zenzie-Gregory B. Smale S.T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 116-127Crossref PubMed Scopus (596) Google Scholar) or to the recently described DPE inDrosophila (consensus (A/G)G(A/T)CGT; Refs. 8.Burke T.W. Kadonaga J.T. Genes Dev. 1996; 10: 711-724Crossref PubMed Scopus (328) Google Scholar and 9.Burke T.W. Kadonaga J.T. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 3020-3031Crossref PubMed Scopus (399) Google Scholar) and may therefore contain a novel downstream core promoter element. Work from a number of laboratories has clearly established that TAFIIs perform critical functions in the binding and the functional readout of core promoter elements distinct from the TATA element (reviewed in Refs. 1.Roeder R.G. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1996; 21: 327-335Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (718) Google Scholar,3.Verrijzer C.P. Tjian R. Trends Biochem Sci. 1996; 21: 338-342Crossref PubMed Scopus (319) Google Scholar, and 4.Burley S.K. Roeder R.G. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1996; 65: 769-799Crossref PubMed Scopus (628) Google Scholar). To test for a role of TAFIIs in LRP-2 downstream promoter sequence function, we examined the function of LRP-2 downstream promoter sequences between +5 and +52 on transcription in a HeLa nuclear extract immunodepleted of TFIID activity (NE[ΔD]; Ref.27.Oelgeschläger T. Tao Y. Kang Y.K. Roeder R.G. Mol Cell. 1998; 1: 925-931Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar). As shown in Fig. 2 B, transcription from the LRP-2 promoter in this extract was completely dependent on the addition of either highly purified recombinant human 6His:TBP or equivalent amounts (TBP content) of immunoaffinity-purified f:TFIID (Fig. 2 A; Refs. 19.Chiang C.M. Ge H. Wang Z. Hoffmann A. Roeder R.G. EMBO J. 1993; 12: 2749-2762Crossref PubMed Scopus (171) Google Scholar and 27.Oelgeschläger T. Tao Y. Kang Y.K. Roeder R.G. Mol Cell. 1998; 1: 925-931Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar). In the presence of f:TFIID, the relative levels of transcription from the parental −120/+52 constructs and the two deletion mutants in NE[ΔD] were comparable with those observed in untreated extract (comparelanes 3, 6, and 9 of Fig.2 B with lanes 1, 3, and4 of Fig. 1 B). Thus, the addition of highly purified f:TFIID (Fig. 2 A) was sufficient to restore LRP-2 downstream sequence functions in NE[ΔD]. Importantly, transcription levels from the LRP-2 promoter containing downstream promoter sequences up to +52 was significantly higher (>5-fold) with f:TFIID than with similar amounts of human 6His:TBP (Fig. 2 B, comparelane 2 with lane 3). This was also true for the −120/+11 construct (lanes 5 and 6), although the difference in absolute transcription levels was somewhat lower (3.4-fold). Despite the very weak absolute transcription levels, transcription from the −120/+4 template was reproducibly higher with 6His:TBP than with f:TFIID (lanes 8 and 9). Taken together, these results demonstrate that LRP-2 downstream sequence function is TAFII-dependent. They also indicate that TAFIIs may actually inhibit TBP function in the absence of LRP-2 downstream promoter sequences, consistent with earlier observations with other core promoters (13.Verrijzer C.P. Chen J.L. Yokomori K. Tjian R. Cell. 1995; 81: 1115-1125Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (257) Google Scholar, 27.Oelgeschläger T. Tao Y. Kang Y.K. Roeder R.G. Mol Cell. 1998; 1: 925-931Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar, 31.Guermah M. Malik S. Roeder R.G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1998; 18: 3234-3244Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Similar results were obtained in analogous experiments using heat-treated HeLa nuclear extracts that lack TFIID activity (Ref. 17.Nakajima N. Horikoshi M. Roeder R.G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1988; 8: 4028-4040Crossref PubMed Scopus (297) Google Scholar; data not shown). To further investigate the role(s) of TAFIIs in LRP-2 downstream promoter sequence function, we carried out DNase I footprinting experiments using radiolabeled DNA fragments containing various LRP-2 promoter variants, immunoaffinity-purified f:TFIID, and partially purified human TFIIA (21.Oelgeschläger T. Chiang C.M. Roeder R.G. Nature. 1996; 382: 735-738Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar). Binding of f:TFIID to a DNA fragment containing LRP-2 promoter sequences from −120 to +52 was relatively weak, presumably due to the low affinity TATA box sequence present in the LRP-2 promoter (Ref. 11.Wobbe C.R. Struhl K. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1990; 10: 3859-3867Crossref PubMed Scopus (239) Google Scholar; see below). However, detectable DNase I protection extended over a broad promoter region from about position −40 to +30 (Fig. 3,lanes 1–4). Importantly, f:TFIID binding induced strong DNase I hypersensitivity centered around positions −50 and −60 upstream of the TAGA element, as well as within the LRP-2 downstream promoter region at positions +7 and +8. Removal of LRP-2 downstream sequences from +11 to +52 resulted in a modest reproducible reduction of overall f:TFIID binding to the LRP-2 promoter but did not affect DNase I hypersensitivity upstream from the TATA element and downstream from the transcription start site (Fig. 3, compare lanes 1–4 with lanes 5–8), in agreement with the modest, yet reproducible impairment of transcription observed in vitro and in vivo (Fig. 1, B, C, and D). Importantly, and in contrast to our observations with the −120/+52 and −120/+11 constructs, further deletion of LRP-2 promoter sequences to +4 did not significantly reduce overall f:TFIID binding but instead completely abolished the induction of DNase I hypersensitivity upstream from the TATA element and downstream from the transcription start site (Fig. 3, compare lanes 9–12 withlanes 5–8). These results suggest that LRP-2 promoter sequences from +5 to +11 are major determinants of f:TFIID·DNA complex formation, consistent with their importance for efficient LRP-2 transcription in vitro and in transfected cells (Fig. 1, B, C, and D). Finally, we assessed the contribution of the nonconsensus LRP-2 TATA element in f:TFIID promoter binding by performing DNase I footprinting assays with a promoter construct containing LRP-2 sequences from −10 to +52, lacking the TAGA element. Surprisingly, we were able to detect weak f:TFIID binding, protecting a region from DNase I digestion downstream of the transcription start site and to around position −40 (Fig. 3, lanes 13–15). Thus, although the TAGA element at position −30 is required for detectable LRP-2 transcription in vitro (25.Knutson A. Hellman P. Akerstrom G. Westin G. DNA Cell Biol. 1998; 17: 551-560Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar), LRP-2 downstream promoter sequences between positions −10 and +52 appear to be sufficient for low affinity f:TFIID binding. Taken together, these observations demonstrate that DNA sequences downstream of the transcription start site contribute to efficient f:TFIID binding. Interestingly, the presence of the downstream region between +5 and +11 did not significantly increase the overall affinity of f:TFIID binding to the LRP-2 promoter (Fig. 3, lanes 5–12) but rather induced strong DNase I hypersensitivity upstream of the TATA element and downstream of the LRP-2 transcription start site. This indicated to us that this particular part of the LRP-2 downstream region may affect the overall topology of the f:TFIID·LRP-2 promoter complex (see below). We attempted unsuccessfully to identify the component(s) of TFIID that contact the LRP-2 downstream promoter region by a photocross-linking method (data not shown) using promoter constructs modified

The African trypanosome Trypanosoma brucei has a digenetic life cycle that involves the insect vector and the mammalian host. This is underscored by biochemical switches in its nutritional requirements. In the insect vector, the parasite relies on amino acid catabolism, but in the mammalian host, it derives its energy exclusively from blood glucose. Glucose transport is facilitated, and constitutes the rate-limiting step in ATP synthesis. Here, we report the cloning of a novel glucose transporter-related gene by heterologous screening of a λEMBL4 genomic library of T. brucei EATRO 164 using a rat liver glucose transporter cDNA clone. Genomic analysis shows that the gene is present as a single copy within the parasite genome. The gene encodes a protein with an estimated molecular mass of 55.9 kDa, which shares only segmental homology with members of the glucose transporter superfamily. Several potential post-translational modification sites including phosphorylation, N-glycosylation, and cotranslational myristoylation sites also punctuate the sequence. It is distinguished from classical transporter proteins by the absence of putative hydrophobic membrane-spanning domains. However, this protein was capable of complementing Schizosaccharomyces pombe glucose transporter mutants. The rescued phenotype conferred the ability of the cells to grow on a broad range of sugars, both monosaccharides and disaccharides. The kinetics of glucose uptake reflected those in T. brucei. In addition to complementation in yeast, we also showed that the gene enhanced glucose uptake in cultured mammalian cells. This is underscored by biochemical switches in its nutritional requirements. In the insect vector, the parasite relies on amino acid catabolism, but in the mammalian host, it derives its energy exclusively from blood glucose. Glucose transport is facilitated, and constitutes the rate-limiting step in ATP synthesis. Here, we report the cloning of a novel glucose transporter-related gene by heterologous screening of a λEMBL4 genomic library of T. brucei EATRO 164 using a rat liver glucose transporter cDNA clone. Genomic analysis shows that the gene is present as a single copy within the parasite genome. The gene encodes a protein with an estimated molecular mass of 55.9 kDa, which shares only segmental homology with members of the glucose transporter superfamily. Several potential post-translational modification sites including phosphorylation, N-glycosylation, and cotranslational myristoylation sites also punctuate the sequence. It is distinguished from classical transporter proteins by the absence of putative hydrophobic membrane-spanning domains. However, this protein was capable of complementing Schizosaccharomyces pombe glucose transporter mutants. The rescued phenotype conferred the ability of the cells to grow on a broad range of sugars, both monosaccharides and disaccharides. The kinetics of glucose uptake reflected those in T. brucei. In addition to complementation in yeast, we also showed that the gene enhanced glucose uptake in cultured mammalian cells. Krebs-Ringer-Hepes yeast extract and supplements trypanosome glucose transporter-related protein The bloodstream forms of Trypanosoma brucei are absolutely dependent on peripheral glucose supply and derive their energy by glycolysis (1.Vickerman K. Br. Med. Bull. 1985; 41: 105-114Crossref PubMed Scopus (478) Google Scholar, 2.Durieux P.O. Schütz Brun R. Köhler P. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1991; 45: 19-28Crossref PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). The glycosome is the major site for glycolysis, and most glycolytic enzymes are compartmentalized here (3.Opperdoes F.R. Annu. Rev. Microbiol. 1987; 41: 127-151Crossref PubMed Scopus (429) Google Scholar). There is evidence suggesting the differential expression of glycolytic enzymes in the bloodstream forms (4.Parsons M. Alexander K. Hill T. Neilsen B. Dovey H.F. Wang C.C. Parasites: Molecular Biology, Drug and Vaccine Design. Wiley-Liss, Inc., New York1990: 247-261Google Scholar). This may be indicative of a differentially expressed glucose transporter, assuming that the two systems operate in tandem. In order to be shunted into the glycolytic pathway, glucose must therefore cross the plasma membrane and then pass through the glycosomal membrane. It might appear that both compartments are equipped with glucose transporters, although it is suggested that the flagellar pocket may serve in solute uptake by endocytosis (5.Coppens I. Opperdoes F.R. Courtroy P.J. Baudhiun P. J. Protozool. 1987; 34: 465-473Crossref PubMed Scopus (179) Google Scholar). Glucose uptake by bloodstream forms is mediated by a facilitated glucose transporter (6.Eisenthal R. Game S. Holman G.D. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1989; 985: 81-89Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar, 7.Gruenberg J. Sharma P.R. Deshusses J. Eur. J. Biochem. 1978; 89: 461-469Crossref PubMed Scopus (43) Google Scholar, 8.Ter Kuile B.H. Opperdoes F.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 857-862Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Kinetic measurements indicate that there are substantial differences between this transporter and that of the mammalian host. Some of these differences include a 20–50-fold higher rate of glucose metabolism than the mammalian host cells (9.von Brand T. Lwoff A. Biochemistry and Physiology of Protozoa. 1. Academic Press, New York1951: 177-234Crossref Google Scholar); insensitivity to cytochalasin B (unpublished observations), and the ability to transport fructose (10.Fry A.J. Towner P. Holman G.D. Eisenthal R. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1993; 60: 9-18Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). Some work has shown that several glucose transporters are present in the kinetoplastids, which differ largely in the stage specificity of expression (11.Bringaud F. Baltz T. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1992; 52: 111-122Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar, 12.Bringaud F. Baltz T. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 1146-1154Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar, 13.Cairns B.R. Collard M.W. Landfear S.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 7682-7686Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 14.Langford C.K. Ewbank S.A. Hanson S.S. Ullman B. Landfear S.M. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1992; 55: 51-64Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). These transporters showed apparent homology to members of the facilitative glucose transporters including the presence of putative transmembrane segments. The kinetics of glucose uptake and sensitivity to known inhibitors of transport were also similar in many respects. However, because those transporters were identified either with variant surface glycoprotein gene probes (11.Bringaud F. Baltz T. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1992; 52: 111-122Crossref PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar) or based on developmental expression (13.Cairns B.R. Collard M.W. Landfear S.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 7682-7686Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar), we reasoned that other unidentified transporters still exist inT. brucei. By heterologous probing with a rat liver glucose transporter cDNA, we isolated and cloned a trypanosome protein that is distinct from any previously reported. Although it has only residual homology to the classical glucose transporters, it was able to rescue fission yeast glucose transporter mutants by supporting growth on sugars, both disaccharides and monosaccharides. This protein may therefore belong to a new class of transporters, or it may be tightly associated with glucose uptake and metabolism. Nature. 1968; 218: 1273-1274Crossref PubMed Scopus (344) Google Scholar). Oligodeoxynucleotides were synthesized on an Applied Biosystems DNA synthesizer model 318A. A genomic λEMBL4 library of T. brucei EATRO 164 was used to infect Q359 cells and plated on 20 × 20-cm agar dishes to yield a confluent lawn of plaques. Plaque lifts were performed according to standard techniques (16.Sambrook J. Fritsch E.F. Maniatis T. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1989Google Scholar) using Hybond N+ (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). The immobilized bacteriophage DNA was screened with a rat liver glucose transporter cDNA (17.Thorens B. Sarkar H.K. Kaback H.R. Lodish H.F. Cell. 1988; 55: 281-290Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (661) Google Scholar) labeled with [α-32P]dATP by random priming using the Multiprime DNA labeling system as directed (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Hybridizations were performed in 50% deionized formamide, 1% SDS, 5× Denhardt's solution, 5× SSC, 5 mm EDTA, pH 7.5, 50 mm sodium phosphate, pH 7.0, and 200 μg/ml salmon sperm DNA, at 42 °C for 18 h. Posthybridization treatment included a moderate stringency wash at 55 °C for 1 h in 1× SSC, 0.1% SDS. The membranes were exposed overnight to Fuji film for autoradiography. Positive isolates were purified by two cycles of screening at decreasing plaque densities. DNA was purified from the positive clones and restriction mapped by Southern blotting and hybridization with the rat cDNA probe. A single strongly hybridizing EcoRI/HindIII fragment from clone LT-10 was gel-purified and directionally cloned into pUC18 to give pTGT-4. Transformants of pTGT-4 in TG1 cells were selected on agar/ampicillin plates. Plasmid DNA for sequencing was isolated from large scale cultures by alkaline lysis and CsCl equilibrium centrifugation. The gene was also cloned into theEcoRI/HindIII sites in M13mp18 and M13mp19 and sequenced (18.Sanger F. Nicklen S. Coulson A.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1977; 74: 5463-5467Crossref PubMed Scopus (52650) Google Scholar) using Sequenase (U. S. Biochemical Corp.). DNA sequences were analyzed using the Staden software program (19.Staden R. Nucleic Acids Res. 1982; 10: 2951-2961Crossref PubMed Scopus (535) Google Scholar). Multiple sequence alignments were performed using the HOMED program of Stockwell (20.Stockwell P.A. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1988; 13: 332-334Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). Data bases were searched using the FASTP program of Lipman and Pearson (21.Lipman D.J. Pearson W.R. Science. 1985; 227: 1435-1441Crossref PubMed Scopus (2546) Google Scholar). Genomic DNA was digested to completion with restriction endonucleases that have only one recognition site within or flanking the gene. Restriction fragments were electrophoresed on 0.8% agarose gels and blotted onto Hybond N+. The insert from pTGT-4 was random-primed and used to probe the blot. Hybridization conditions were similar to the above except that a final high stringency wash at 65 °C with 1× SSC, 0.05% SDS was included. Total RNA was isolated from bloodstream forms of the parasite according to the method of Chomczynski and Saachi (22.Chomczynski P. Saachi N. Anal. Biochem. 1987; 162: 156-159Crossref PubMed Scopus (63169) Google Scholar). Approximately 10 μg was electrophoresed on a 1% formaldehyde agarose gel and transferred to Hybond N+. The blot was probed with pTGT-4 as described above. Hybridization and posthybridization conditions were similar to those employed above. mRNA was isolated from the parasite using the Poly(A) Quik mRNA isolation kit (Stratagene). 2 μg of mRNA was annealed to 10 pmol of [γ-32P]ATP-labeled oligonucleotide C4 (AATTCCAGTGCCTAACCCCTA), complementary to nucleotides 853–873. Primer extension was performed using the avian myeloblastosis virus primer extension system as instructed (Promega). Oligonucleotide C4 was also used to sequence pTGT-4. Both sequencing reaction and primer extension products were co-electrophoresed on 8% polyacrylamide gel (National Diagnostics). TheEcoRI and HindIII cloning sites of the gene were filled in with the Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase and cloned into the SmaI site of the eukaryotic expression vector pSVL to give pSVL2.5. Insert orientation was determined by restriction mapping and confirmed by sequencing. DNA was isolated from the appropriate clone. COS-7 cells were grown in Dulbecco's minimal essential medium (Life Technologies, Inc.) in 3.5-cm dishes at 37 °C, 5% CO2. At 80–90% confluence, the cells were transfected separately with 10 μg each of pSVL2.5 and pSVL, using Lipofectin (Life Technologies, Inc.) according to the manufacturer's instructions. After 72 h, the cells were washed twice with Krebs-Ringer-Hepes (KRH)1buffer, pH 7.6 (10 mm Hepes, 140 mm NaCl, 2 mm KCl, 1 mm MgCl2, 2 mm KH2PO4, 1 mmCaCl2) equilibrated at 37 °C. They were preincubated for 30 min at 37 °C in 500 μl of fresh KRH. This was replaced with a 500-μl mixture of 100 μmd-glucose and 2 μCi of [3H]2-deoxy-d-glucose (6.6 Ci/mmol; Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). After an appropriate incubation time, glucose uptake was terminated by adding 2 ml of ice-cold KRH containing 100 μg/ml phloridzin, which was then aspirated. The cells were washed two more times. To control for background or nonspecific binding, the stopping buffer was added to the cells before adding the radiolabeled 2-deoxyglucose. l-[3H]leucine (166 Ci/mmol; Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) uptake control assays were also performed as above, and uptake was terminated with ice-cold KRH. All time points were run in duplicate. The cells were then solubilized in 500 μl 1% SDS at room temperature for 30 min and transferred to a vial containing 10 ml of scintillation mixture and counted in an LKB Wallac counter. This was performed according to Milbradt and Höfer (23.Milbradt B. Höfer M. Microbiology. 1994; 140: 2617-2623Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar). The insert from pTGT-4, previously cloned into theHindIII/EcoRI site of pGEM7 to give pGEM2.5, was subcloned as a HindIII/XhoI fragment into the yeast shuttle vector pCMVL predigested with HindIII andXhoI. Recombinants were identified and verified by restriction analysis. The new construct, pCMVLTGT, was used to transform the fission yeast glucose transporter mutant YGS-5 (leu1–32 ght1 h +), by the lithium acetate/PEG method (24.Sherman F. Fink G.R. Hicks J.B. Methods in Yeast Genetics. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1986Google Scholar). Transformants were selected on synthetic minimal medium, pH 4.5 (0.67% yeast nitrogen base, 4.7% gluconic acid (potassium salt), 1.5% agar supplemented with leucine drop-out medium (Bio 101, Inc.)) after 2–3 days of growth at 30 °C. These were replica-plated on minimal agar medium lacking gluconic acid but supplemented with 3% glucose, fructose, and maltose or 0.05% 2-deoxyglucose/gluconic acid, with or without leucine. Alternatively, the cells were also grown on YES/agar medium (0.5% yeast extract, 1.5% agar supplemented with 0.01% each of uracil, adenine, leucine, lysine, and histidine) also containing each of the above sugars. Cultures were incubated at 30 °C for 2–3 days to assess growth. YGS-5 cells and SP-Q01 (wild type; (leu1–32 h −) Stratagene) were used as negative and positive controls, respectively. Yeast cells were grown at 30 °C in YES medium and harvested at midlog phase. The culture was centrifuged for 10 min at 10,000 rpm in a Sorvall centrifuge. They were washed twice with PBS and then resuspended in the same buffer at 2–3A 600 units. Glucose uptake was initiated using 2 ml of cell suspension in universal polystyrene tubes (Bibi Sterilin) by adding 5 μCi of [3H]2-deoxy-d-glucose (8.8 Ci/mmol; Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) and rapidly mixed by pipetting. Aliquots of 200 μl were taken at various time intervals and rapidly centrifuged through spin filters (Qiagen) at 13,000 rpm (10–20 s). Radioactivity was measured in an LKB Wallac liquid scintillation counter. Logarithmic phase cultures of YGS-5 cells and Tgtrep-transformed cells were diluted to anA 600 of 0.2 in minimal medium supplemented with 25 mm sugars. For YGS-5, leucine was also added to the medium. The cultures were grown at 30 °C, and optical densities of these cultures were measured at various time points at 600 nm. A permissive growth medium, YEL/gluconate (0.5% yeast extract, 0.2% casamino acids, 4.7% gluconate, pH 4.5) was also used to ensure that both cultures had equivalent growth rates. To identify the putative glucose transporter, we used the rat liver glucose transporter cDNA to screen a genomic library of T. brucei EATRO 164 in λEMBL4. A single strongly hybridizing clone (LT-10) was selected for further characterization. Restriction mapping coupled with Southern blotting using the cDNA probe identified a 2.5-kilobase pairEcoRI/HindIII insert (Fig.1). This was subcloned into pUC18 to yield pTGT-4 and sequenced by dideoxy chain termination. One open reading frame with a coding capacity of 55.9 kDa was identified. A Kozak consensus sequence and clusters of purine residues, which are the basic requirements for efficient mRNA translation, flank the translation initiation codon (25.Kozak M. Nucleic Acids Res. 1981; 9: 5233-5252Crossref PubMed Scopus (829) Google Scholar). No in-frame methionines were identified upstream of this codon. Using this gene to probe Southern blots of genomic fragments generated with enzymes that have unique restriction sites within the gene, single bands were observed in all cases. Similar results were obtained using restriction sites that flank the gene. A unique band corresponding in size to the fragment from LT-10 was also detected in a HindIII/EcoRI digest (Fig. 2). These results probably suggest that the gene is present as a single copy within the parasite genome. To further confirm that the gene was trypanosome-derived, primers based on the nucleotide sequence of the gene were synthesized and used to amplify genomic and cDNA fragments by polymerase chain reaction. DNA sequencing showed that the genomic and cDNA clones were identical both to the λEMBL4 clone and to a clone obtained from an enriched genomic library (data not shown). Northern blot analysis using the gene as a probe showed a transcript of about 6.2 kilobase pairs (Fig. 3 A). This is larger than the coding capacity of the gene but the size may be due to the presence of untranslated sequences or to the transcript being part of a polycistron. To identify the 5′-end of the mRNA, we performed primer extension.
